Formerly Bonny used to be emphatically *the* oil river, but latterly, year by year, its export of that commodity has been diminishing, whilst that of all the other rivers has been increasing. It is an extraordinary fact that, as the price of palm oil has been diminishing month by month, the produce of it has been increasing. This simply arises from the fact that the African is too lazy to work more than is absolutely necessary to obtain what he requires, or thinks he requires. Consequently, as the value obtained in kind for a puncheon of palm oil has diminished, he brings more oil to market to obtain an equivalent supply of gin, gunpowder, clothes, &c., to what he previously received, and so the very proceeding which arises in the first instance from a lowering in the price of the oil at home has a tendency to still further decrease prices by glutting the market.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Party Criticisms on Ashanti War Operations', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'but can scarcely fail to be regarded with a mixture of sorrow and disgust by all who are not blinded by ignorance or party feeling, which, like the snake, converts the most delicious things into poison. We have never, in African matters, been partizans of either Conservative or Liberal Administrations. Both, and equally, have, to our mind, dealt neglectfully and unwisely, and therefore unjustly and injuriously, with Western Africa. But when we see an attempt to overwhelm the late Administration with such questions as the following, we become for a moment partizans of the late Government, notwithstanding all its errors and shortcomings, of which we have felt personally the sad effects. "How did the quarrel with King Koffee Kalcalli arise? In obedience to what principle of national duty did we send an expedition beyond the Prah? What advantage have we secured by burning down Kumasi, and shattering the power of the only negro State which offered any semblance of a stable government? What do we hope to gain by peace and friendship with the Ashantees, supposing that we have inclined them thereto by the measures we have taken for their destruction? We have to satisfy our national conscience on all these points, or else we shall have won what is something less than even a barren triumph." This is meant, no doubt, to be a formidable indictment, yet the answer is simple enough. The quarrel with King Kalcalli dates from his predecessor's reign, in 1862, when the Gold Coast authorities refused to deliver up the refugee "Ganim." No peace has since been made. It was always understood that the Ashantees were busy accumulating ammunition, and the Dutch withdrawal and Elmina discontent, brought the slumbering hostilities to a head again. It is not difficult to prove that it was our duty to rid the Protectorate of them. The only error was, that that was not understood at the commencement, before they half-ruined the country and bearded us in our seacoast forts. It being our duty to get rid of them, it must have been equally our duty to get rid of them effectually. This could only be done by what has since been done—by following them into their own territory, destroying their military prestige, burning their capital, and shattering the power "of the only negro State which offered any semblance of a stable government." Detestable government, might well have been said. As to what we hope to gain by peace and friendship with them, after the measures we have taken for their destruction, the reply is not difficult. Having gained a full assurance of peace for the Protectorate, by destroying the military prestige and power of its only enemy, we give that humbled enemy liberty to carry on, as heretofore, that trade with the sea-coast without which he cannot live; and which he could not have ventured on without a treaty, because the Assins, Wassaws, Denkeras, &c., would have murdered and plundered the traders, on the ground of their being still enemies. The Ashantees, and the people of their formerly tributary states and others beyond, cannot exist without communication with the Coast, for that most indispensable article, salt, and many others. We wish them to have these; we have an advantage in their coming to buy them in our territory: we guarantee them, by treaty, peaceable access, on certain terms. This will give them again their old advantages as intermediate traders between the seacoast and the people beyond. In the supposition that there is an engagement on the part of the King of Ashanti that there shall be no more human sacrifices, this is sneered at as having "a shining moral appearance." When we reflect on the myriads of human beings that have been offered there in sacrifice, until the whole atmosphere of the capital was poisoned by the sickly exhalation from human gore and putrefying carcases, we feel ineffable disgust at this "shining moral appearance." If no other good end had been obtained by us, this one alone, if obtained, is worthy of a great Christian civilized nation; and, should be deemed, if power has duties as well as rights, a full and exceeding recompense for the effort we have made, even though the "sacrifice of other lives which it has entailed" should all be debited to this account, which we deny. As to the war "having been always unnecessary," we have not space to join issue on the point as it deserves. All we shall say is, it can only be deemed unnecessary, provided it could be established that, if earlier measures had been taken by the Cape Coast Government to aid the native tribes of the Protectorate, they alone would have sufficed for rolling back the invasion. We always believed this might have been effected. But even then the war could scarcely be deemed unnecessary, as the territories would have been continually threatened with invasion and devastation, murder, and all other enormities of barbarian inroads. There was no permanent remedy to be found, no permanent security to be obtained, save by the invasion of Ashanti. This has been, happily, accomplished, and however party feeling may suffer at the too speedy and economical success, we rejoice that there is no longer any probability of our ever having again to deplore an Ashanti invasion of the Gold Coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1874-03-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_03_1874#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLISH CIVILISATION IN THE NIGER REGION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"And what impression has your tour made?"—"We have returned well satisfied with the work of administration and also with the commercial development which is going on. The trade in forest products is growing, and the plantations which have been started at Abutchi, Nkissi, and other places for the purpose of instructing the natives in the cultivation of coffee, cocoa, and other products hitherto unknown in these regions are making satisfactory progress. Although tribal wars are still frequent among the pagans, they are greatly diminished in number and intensity, and disputes are so frequently referred to the Company's district courts for decision as to demand a much larger staff than the present petty revenue of the Company can afford. I was especially struck with the great advance that has taken place of late years in the intelligence of the natives who have come in contact with Europeans. Members of tribes formerly savages and cannibals are now competent to act as domestic servants, interpreters, pilots, engineers, and even captains of steamers. No doubt they retain many of their barbarous habits, as the practices of generations are not changed in a day."

"Has slave-raiding been checked to any extent?"—"The raiding of the Mohammedan slave-dealers into the pagan regions under our jurisdiction has undoubtedly been checked by means of the careful disposition of our troops along the Benue river. The number of troops set apart for this work has had to be considerably augmented, and we hope that this will lead to a large development in trade and in the cultivation of the land in regions which have hitherto been depopulated by the slave-raiders."

"Does this active interference with the slave trade not raise up enemies?"—"Notwithstanding these operations, the relations with the Mohammedan Emirs continue on the whole friendly, the principal exception being the Emir of Muri, a province to the north of the Upper Benue. During their journey they had to pass the Kokofos, and it is alleged that they were set upon and killed, and their goods plundered by the Kokofos. Matters for some time past have been in a very strained state between the two tribes, and it was said that this last act of the Kokofos will probably lead to a fresh outbreak of hostilities. This is what happened with the Shi, and in Burundi and Rwanda. The whole of the ancient Fon kingdom of Dahomey and the western half of Yorubaland as well as Borgu are located within this 'gap'. [{'id': 68, 'article_title': "CAPTAIN BURTON'S ASCENT OF THE CAMEROONS MOUNTAIN.", 'full_section_title': "CAPTAIN BURTON'S ASCENT OF THE CAMEROONS MOUNTAIN.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-22', 'issue_date': '23_12_1862', 'content': 'and boulders being loose and rolling. Seven hours had been occupied in finishing the last five miles of the ascent, and he hoped to return in three. The mercury fell to 40 deg. as he passed Mount Helen. Twilight came on, then a darkness that could be felt. He was compelled to halt. The cry of the Kroo-boy was heard at the spring, and soon firesticks marked the place of the camp. After the supper of hungry men, the party retired to rest, but not to sleep; the sun and wind had sorely burned their hands and faces, their legs ached, and spasmodic cramps seized their limbs.

A variety of expeditions followed this first exploration. Mr. Saker returned, with Mr. Robert Smith, on the 5th of January, and on the 13th he made the third ascent, and was the first to boil the thermometer upon Victoria Peak. On the 15th Mr. Saker again returned to Victoria.

A final ascent was begun on the 27th January. The night following the cold was so intense, that the mercury fell to 33 deg. 5 min. The waterproof coats of the travellers were white with hoar, and the peak was powdered with frozen dew. Before leaving the peak Captain Burton was able to discover a complete solfaterra, lying to the north-east of Albert Crater. Smoke arose in long puffy volumes from long lines of white marl and sulphur. This discovery accounts for the many detached reports of flames seen issuing from the mountain by the cloth merchants of Cameroons River and the people of Fernando Po. A hailstorm signalised the day of descent.

On the 31st January the camp at Mann's Spring was broken up. On the 2nd February the scattered bungalows of Victoria were reached, where the travellers were hospitably received by Mrs. Saker, who had purposely remained till their return.

"These lines," says Captain Burton, in conclusion, "will show the adaptability of the Cameroons Mountain for a sanitarium, a colony, or a convict station. A locale which shows every morning hoar-frost during the hot season, in a region removed but 4 degs. from the Equator, is not to be despised in the days when it is proposed to remove Calcutta to Simla. The Anglo-Scandinavian race cannot, it is true, thrive in all climates; but there are few, and those are valueless, in which choice of site could not make him a cosmopolite."

Our readers will, we are sure, be glad to receive the disinterested and most valuable testimony of this celebrated traveller to the truthfulness of all that our pages have contained of the salubrity and fitness of the vicinity of Amboises Bay for a missionary or commercial settlement. Between the north and the south of Africa spread about 7,000,000 square miles of almost unknown land. Upon the character of this region science has spent its speculations, and the exploration of it has been the hard work of ages. Africa, in fact, has been the world's huge problem. From Cæsar to Speke, the origin of the Nile has been mankind's greatest puzzle. Unsolved though it be, the attempts to trace it out have been of the greatest service. No longer esteemed a howling wilderness, or a death-stricken morass, the interior of Africa, from the southern border of Sahara down to our own limits, we know to be singularly fertile, and by no means insalubrious. The western shore, north of Walwisch Bay, gives ample evidence that a wealthy country lies beyond—a country rich in minerals and vegetation—blessed in all save the savage races that seal it up from the view of civilization. Going north, we find, near the equator, a tract of splendid hill-land, where the Cameroon Mountains reach to a height of 14,000 or 15,000 feet, and where the climate is so genial, that Captain Burton recommended its fitness for a penal settlement. Here we have come to the most remarkable part of the continent. Beyond the Cameroons extends that vast depression which intersects Africa, at a high altitude, from the equator to the Cape. Then, on the other side of the still unknown territory, we come to the wonderful lake-land, whose inland seas, fringed by the palm-growth of the tropics, are overshadowed by the snowy peaks, and embraced by the crescent arms of the mystic Mountains of the Moon. Here, in what may naturally be regarded as the hottest part of Africa, lying exactly across the equator, is a land which, according to Speke and Grant, is one of the finest in the world. Owing to its height above the sea-level, the climate is singularly pleasant, and is so far from being excessively hot, that Captain Grant walked through the whole of it in woollen clothing, and slept every night between blankets. 750 different specimens brought away by these travellers attest the abundance and variety of the vegetation there. All the necessaries and many luxuries of savage life grow without much effort, and the natives lead an easy and somewhat gluttonous existence, in the rank enjoyment of the many gifts of nature. From all we know, and that recent travellers have told us, the whole of East Africa, between Natal and the equator, bears the same character. Dr. Livingstone has found the cotton plant growing abundantly throughout the valleys and river plains north of the Zambezi. On this side of that river exists a country that is utterly unexplored as yet. On the map this region presents a blank, and a dotted line only marks the supposed course of the Limpopo as it goes to the sea. What is known of this tract, however, and by slow degrees it is being trenched upon, is altogether favourable. The large organised hunting stations which are now established in the Trans-Vaal, sending out yearly many detachments of trained hunters into the adjacent territories, are gradually opening up this darkly hid land, and we hear that recent hunters describe what they have seen of it in most glowing terms. They say that for beauty of aspect and natural fertility it exceeds any of the southern divisions, and the people of Moselekatsc, who rules as the emperor of it, are known to be in advance of the tribes on this side of them. Here, it must be remembered, is the ancient Sofala, presumed to be the Ophir referred to in the Bible, and to this day gold ornaments sometimes reach us through natives who have received them from that mysterious locality. **31**"}, {'id': 5835, 'article_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'full_section_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-9', 'issue_date': '06_05_1889', 'content': 'The main Ituri, at the distance of 680 miles from its mouth, is 125 yards wide, 9 ft. deep, and has a current of three knots; it appears to run parallel with the Nyanza. Near that group of cones and hills affectionately named Mount Schweinfurth, Mount Junker, and Mount Speke, I would place its highest source. Draw three or four respectable streams draining into it from the crest of the plateau overlooking the Albert Nyanza, and two or three respectable streams flowing into it from north-westerly, let the main stream flow south-west to near north lat. 1°, give it a bow-like form north lat. 1° to north lat. 1°50, then let it flow with curves and bends down to north lat. 1° 17' near Yambunya, and you have a sketch of the course of the Aruwimi, or Ituri, from the highest source down to its mouth, and the length of this Congo tributary will be 800 miles. We have travelled on it and along its banks for 680 miles; on our first march to the Nyanza for 156 miles along its banks or near its vicinity; we returned to obtain our boat from Kilonga-Longa's; then we conveyed the boat to the Nyanza for as many miles again; or 480 miles we traversed its flanks or voyaged on its waters to hunt up the rear column of the expedition; or as many miles we must retrace our steps to the Albert Nyanza for the third time. You will therefore agree with me that we have sufficient knowledge of this river for all practical purposes.

On May 25, 1888, Emin Pasha's Soudanese were drawn up in line to salute the advance column as it marched in file towards the Ituri river from the Nyanza. Half an hour after we parted, I was musing, as I walked, of the Pasha and his steamer, when my gun-bearer cried out, "See, Sir, what a big mountain; it is covered with salt!" I gazed in the direction he pointed out, and there sure enough a blue mountain of prodigious height and mass. This, then, must be the Ruwenzori, which the natives said had something white, like the metal of my lamp, on the top. By prismatic compass-bearing, the centre of the summit bore 215 deg. (magnetic) from a spot five miles from the shore of the Nyanza. I should estimate its distance to be quite fifty miles from where we stood. Whether it is Mount Gordon Bennett or not I am uncertain. Against the supposition is the fact that I saw no snow on the latter in 1876, that its shape is vastly different, and that Ruwenzori is a little too far west for the position I gave of Gordon Bennett, and I doubt that Gordon Bennett Mount could be seen from a distance of eighty geographical miles in an atmosphere not very remarkable for its clearness. I should say that the snow line seemed to be about 1,000 ft. from the summit. There is plenty of room for both Ruwenzori and Gordon Bennett in the intervening space between Beatrice Gulf and the Albert Nyanza.'}, {'id': 5935, 'article_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'full_section_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-7', 'issue_date': '02_12_1889', 'content': 'A letter of great interest has been received by the Royal Geographical Society from Mr. Stanley, giving some of the geographical results of his expedition.

Lieut. Stairs in June attempted to reach the summit of the snowy Ruwenzori, which Mr. Stanley assures us is identical with the "Mountains of the Moon" of the ancients. Lieut. Stairs only reached a height of 10,600 ft., progress being stopped by three deep ravines, covered with dense vegetation, that lay between them and the nearest snowy peak, which rose to a further height of 6,000 ft. The mountain sides up to 8,000 ft. are inhabited by a people who disappeared before Lieut. Stairs and his party. Bamboo forests clothe the lower mountain sides, above which was a dense growth of heaths rising to 20 ft. The night was bitterly cold, a great contrast to the valley they had left, and yet the thermometer registered 60 deg. when the party turned in for the night. The upper part of the peak before him Lieut. Stairs could see was devoid of vegetation. The top is crowned with a mass of jagged and precipitous rock, and has a distinct crater-like form. In the distance another peak could be seen having a similar form. Lieut. Stairs concludes that the Ruwenzori is really an extinct volcano; the whole having a resemblance to the mountains of Auvergne.

Mr. Stanley's own notes on the physical geography of the lake region are highly interesting. If, he says, you draw a straight line from the debouchere of the Nile from Lake Albert in a south-west direction, you measure a broad line of subsidence from twenty to fifty miles wide, in the centre of the African Continent. On the west of this is a great upland rising to 3,000 ft. To the east is another upland, rising from 1,000 ft. to 3,000 ft. and trending gently eastwards on the Unyoro plateau. In this section lies the Albert Nyanza. In the south section, only fifty miles long, lies Lake Albert Edward and the plains between the lake and the mountain. Thus, Lake Albert Edward is comparatively small, not more than half the length of the north lake. The part of the Semliki valley which extends from the lake south-westerly is very level; and, in Mr. Stanley's opinion, of recent formation. At seventy-five miles from the Albert Nyanza the valley attains a height of about 900 ft. above the lake, and then the forest region ends, and a new climate is reached.'}, {'id': 6721, 'article_title': 'AFRICA AND ITS TRADE POSSIBILITIES.', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICA AND ITS TRADE POSSIBILITIES.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-6', 'issue_date': '02_03_1896', 'content': 'On Feb. 13, an interesting lecture, entitled "A Naturalist on the Mountains of the Moon," was delivered at the Royal Institution, Liverpool, under the auspices of the Liverpool Geographical Society, by Mr. G. F. Scott Elliot. The lecture was followed with much interest as an exposition from an authority on the subject. Mr. Scott Elliot, by his recent visit to Ruwenzori, has afforded additional information about this magnificent range of mountains in Central Africa, and his treatment of the subject was graphic and most informing. The address was made the more interesting by a series of limelight views. After touching on the character of Africa generally, the lecturer proceeded to give an account of the mountain Ruwenzori, the various difficulties in climbing the primeval forest, its inhabitants, the bamboo zone, the peat mosses, and the various tribes round the mountain. The occurrence of recent volcanic craters, and the manner in which the cloud hangs over the mountain all day long, only disappearing about sunset, was fully illustrated by slides from photographs taken by the lecturer. The lecturer described his experiences. Leopards attacked his camp, and very nearly killed two of his porters. A woman was carried off by a lioness, and he vainly attempted to rescue her. Elephants were extremely abundant round the mountain. The Natives were usually friendly, though the difficulty of obtaining supplies was often considerable, and on one occasion three of his men were attacked by them, and one very severely wounded. His march to the South was one of extraordinary difficulty, as his caravan consisted only of fourteen men, and the people were in places extremely unfriendly, and on one occasion attacked his porters. The future value of these little-known regions was shown by him to depend mainly on three factors—First, the natural wild resources, as rubber, palm oil, minerals, and ivory; secondly, the prospects of plantation by Europeans; and thirdly, the health of Europeans. The country between 3,000 and 5,000 feet had been proved to be valuable for plantations of coffee and tobacco. It is only in Africa above 5,000 feet that there is any possibility of a real colony being formed. The lecturer expressed his opinion that with the knowledge we have now of these parts, the Masai Highlands certainly appear to be quite healthy enough for Europeans to live and bring up children; but that so far there is no sufficient inducement for colonisation at present. Then, turning to the needs of Great Britain at the present time, he suggested that the three main requisites at present were—first, that our imports of food and raw material should come from our own Colonies; secondly, new markets; and thirdly, an outlet for our capital and population, both of which were unnaturally locked up in Great Britain. These new countries were, according to him, exactly adapted to answer those three urgent necessities.'}]

CONSUL O'NEILL ON HIS DISCOVERIES IN EASTERN AFRICA.", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Consul O'Neill delivered an address on July 8th, in Edinburgh, before the Geographical Society of Scotland, on his discoveries in Eastern Africa. After alluding to the services which Scotland has rendered to geographical science, especially in the person of Livingstone, Mr. O'Neill described the circumstances which induced him to resolve to fill up, as far as possible, the great blank in the map of Eastern Africa. The results of his journeys Mr. O'Neill summarised as follows:—

"Briefly, the chief results have been to open up three new routes between the Nyassa district and the coast: 1, between Mozambique and Lake Shirwa and Blantyre; 2, from Blantyre to the Portuguese settlements of Angoche and Parapato; 3, from Quillimane to Blantyre. You know the length of time it took to get overland to Lake Nyassa from the east coast. Many of you remember the hardships encountered by Bishop Steere when getting over the same ground. The Nyassa may now be reached by the longest route in thirty days, and by that from Quillimane to Blantyre in fourteen. The country you pass over is well-populated, food abundant, and the people peaceable, helpful, and industrious. There are difficulties of course, African travel is never without them; but any or all of the three routes I have laid down may be constantly traversed by Europeans, and become most valuable channels for the development of the trade and agriculture of the country. In my journeys I have been fortunate enough to discover three minor lakes: one, Lake Lidedi, just south of the Rovuma, and close to Lake Nargadi, of which Livingstone first heard as he passed north of that river upon his last travels. The others are Lake Amaramba and Cheuta, which have their outlet in the River Lujenda. When in the neighbourhood of these lakes I closely investigated the question of the supposed connexion of Lake Shirwa with the Lujenda drainage system, and satisfied myself that there was no point of junction between them. Lake Shirwa is divided from the Lakes Cheuta and Amaramba by a broad elevated ridge of sandy soil, lightly wooded and covered with thick undergrowth, and I have nowhere detected trace of inundation or evidence of the rising of Lake Shirwa above the level of its foot. It is possible that a subterranean junction exists, and this view is held by many natives."

Mr. O'Neill dwelt upon the importance of a reliable meridian in the interior for the traveller. He described the very interesting evidences of glacial action met with in the hilly regions, and stated he had never met with any traces of subsequent volcanic action, and that he doubts the hypotheses respecting volcanic disturbance. After leaving the river Dowa the country would vary in altitude from 2,000 to 3,500 feet, with peaks rising 2,000 feet higher. South of 4°9 lat. it became gradually flatter and lower, and there was less rainfall. There were many evidences of volcanic action, and iron ore was found in abundance, as well as coarse granite, and mountains of shining white quartz ammonites were also found near the Dawa. With regard to the course of the Omo river, he expressed the belief that it flowed east, and was identical with the Juba. This opinion was strengthened when he discovered that the river Nianam, which flowed into Lake Rudolf, rose about 120 miles north of that lake. The party came to a large and warlike tribe called the Arbore, inhabiting half of the valley above Lake Stefanie. In contrast to the Arbore, the many little tribes further north received the party with every show of friendship. Dr. Smith gave an account of one of these tribes—the Dume. "These Dume," he said, "are dwarfs, their average height being only five feet—we saw none over five feet two inches,—woolly haired, and very black, with flat noses and large lips. They resemble other dwarf tribes found in Africa. But they have very graceful, well-formed bodies. They lived in little hamlets composed of about fifty small huts each, and scattered among the mountains. They owned goats and sheep and raised a little millet. The other tribes visited by the explorers were friendly, with the exception of occasional attempts at petty thieving. The rough mountainous country presented every obstacle to progress. There were no roads, and they had to make paths over ridges 2,000 feet high above the surrounding country. However, Lake Rudolf was near, and Dr. Smith and his party were to be the first to reach it from the east. The expedition had been a hard one, but the party achieved all they set out to do, and more. Dr. Smith then set out for the north along the Nianam, eventually finding himself in an open valley where the ripe durrha was waving to and fro, the goats were nibbling at the soft green grass, and noises from a score of villages reached his ears. The Natives were the most sociable and hospitable black people yet seen. They were very black, and of medium height. They were far above the average in civilisation. Their ornaments and articles of daily use were wonderfully well made. Having come into contact with no Native traders, they possessed nothing in the way of beads or brass. They almost fought with one another to sell anything they had for a string or two of the cheaper sort of beads. He bought supplies of coffee, meal, and tobacco, and some ivory. As to Lake Rudolf itself, Dr. Smith could add nothing to the accounts furnished by Lieutenant Von Hohnel. The different species of insects numbered three thousand. Besides these, there were many plants, butterflies and mammals collected. The paper was illustrated by many photographs of the country and the people.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-02-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_02_1896#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Stanley has addressed an interesting letter to the secretary of the Royal Geographical Society, in which the explorer enters minutely into the geographical results of his expedition, into the character and relations of the different tribes met with, and the nature of the products of one of the most remarkable countries of Africa. "Until we penetrated and marched through it, this region was entirely unexplored and untrodden by either white or Arab." His description of some characteristics of the forest which had to be penetrated is worth quoting. The difficulties "consisted of creepers ranging from 6in. to 15in. in diameter, swinging across the path in bowlines or loops, sometimes massed and twisted together; also of a low dense bush, occupying the sites of old clearings, which had to be carved through before a passage was possible. Where years had elapsed since the clearings had been abandoned, we found a young forest and the spaces between the trees choked with climbing plants, vegetable creepers, and tall plants. This kind had to be tunnelled through before an inch of progress could be made." This is the forest through which Livingstone struggled his way in the Manyuema country in the months before Stanley relieved him. Mr. Stanley shows that the region traversed by him is probably the most extensive forest region in Africa, a region resembling the forest region of South America. Mr. Stanley has definitely settled the courses of an important affluent of the Congo and its tributaries; he has defined the southern limits of the Albert Nyanza, and found that it is rapidly decreasing; he has all but established the fact of the existence of a separate lake to the south, which probably drains into the Congo and not into the Nile; and no doubt on his return he will tell us more of the snowy mountain rivalling Kilimanjaro, far away to the south-east of his standpoint on the west shore of Albert Nyanza. It seems clear that the natural outlet of the region around Albert Nyanza is not by the Aruwimi, but eastwards by Victoria Nyanza and British East Africa. The following extract from Mr. Stanley's letter will afford a fair idea of some of the geographical results:—

The Aruwimi has many names—the Dudu, Biyerre, Luhali, the Nevva, Nowelle-Itiré. For the last 300 miles of its course, but upward to its source, it has a singular, wide-spreading fame under the name of Ituri. The aborigines of the Nyanza, the open plateau and forest tribes down to within a few miles of the Kepoko, all unite in calling it the Ituri.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-05-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Though lapse of time has deprived Kilimanjaro of some of the novelty which it possessed, it is still, unless we except the Great Atlas, the most interesting, as it is believed to be the loftiest, of the African mountains. Even the stolid and unromantic Masai natives have never lost the awe with which the sublime spectacle of the colossal "Ngaje Nagi" impressed their fathers. Heaved up during some of those vast volcanic convulsions of which it remains the principal record, it is likely to be the goal for an ever-increasing troop of scientific pilgrims. It may even become a sanatorium for Zanzibar and Mozambique. Although it stands completely apart from the neighbouring heights, Kilimanjaro is only one of many summits which crown the east ridge of the great plateau of Equatorial Africa. F. Scott-Elliot, who accompanied the Anglo-French Boundary Commission to Sierra Leone, has prepared a report to the Colonial Office, on the botany and geology of that Colony. Mr. Scott-Elliot says that this country seems to be everywhere underlaid by a gneissose or granitoid rock, varying in appearance from a coarse red or gray granite to a foliated gneiss. This rock appears on the seacoast at Sierra Leone, and forms the tops of most of the higher plateaux: thus the Sugarloaf at Sierra Leone consists of a rock of this nature, and it also forms the broad watershed between Fulaba and Farana, which separates the Scarcies, Rokelle, and Niger drainage areas. This rock, though common and apparently fundamental everywhere, is not often seen on the surface. Almost the whole of the country between the sea level and 2,000 feet is covered by varieties of a reddish laterate or iron-pan, sometimes hard and barren, but usually porous, easily worked, and of a fertile nature. On the top of Mount Kofin he found a thick band of horizontal sandstones, which struck him as being similar to the so-called Nubian sandstones seen about Wady Halfa, on the Nile. There is also a very well-marked dolerite or basalt flow in the north-west corner of the English sphere of influence, traces of which were found at Wallia and Buyabuya, on the Scarcies River, and which forms a dyke twenty to thirty miles long, on the summit of the hills about Ninia and Duunia in the Talla country. In the immediate neighbourhood of this flow there are some much hardened slates or argillites, and the country is especially fertile where fragments of this dolerite are mingled with gneiss and sandstone. The dolerite itself is used by the natives as hones for sharpening knives, &c. The only mineral of importance is iron, of which the country contains a very large amount. There is a peculiarly rich belt of titaniferous iron ore in the hills behind Sierra Leone. Judging from the colour there would seem to be a very large amount of iron in the country. It is not at all unusual to find the smelting places of the natives in certain districts. In other respects the country seems destitute of mineral wealth, though Mr. Elliot could not speak with any certainty. The soil, so far as the Commission saw, could be roughly grouped into three classes. First, that of the plateaux and hills about 2,000 feet, or sometimes descending to 1,000 feet, which is due to the disintegration of gneiss or granite rocks. Second, the red laterite, which covers the lower hills from the sea level to 1,000 or 2,000 feet. Third, the alluvium, due either to the action of the mangroves along the coast, or to the rivers and streams inland. The appendices to the report add materially to its value as a contribution towards our knowledge of this part of West Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-07-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_07_1893#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}]

hh: The volcanic activity in Africa, exemplified by the Cameroons Mountain and other regions, has played a crucial role in shaping the continent's geological history and landscapes.
result: The claim that volcanic activity in Africa, exemplified by the Cameroons Mountain and other regions, has played a crucial role in shaping the continent's geological history and landscapes is supported by observations from The African Times but not addressed in the General History of Africa textbook. The textbook primarily focuses on historical, social, and economic developments, such as the migration of peoples, societal transformations, colonial impacts, and new food sources, without mentioning geological phenomena or volcanic activity. This absence highlights a focus on human history rather than geological aspects. In contrast, The African Times articles provide details supporting the claim, noting the volcanic nature of the Cameroons Mountain, confirmed by Captain Burton's exploration, and its fertile volcanic soil conducive to agriculture. The articles also highlight the volcanic features of Kilimanjaro, with its lava fields and unique hydrological characteristics, and the volcanic origins of the Cape de Verde Islands and the active Peak of Teneriffe. These details illustrate the significant impact of volcanic activity on Africa's geological features and landscapes, aligning with the claim, though the articles do not explicitly connect these features to the continent's broader geological history, which could be seen as a limitation in addressing the claim's full scope.

[{'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Cameroon coast and its hinterland 14 > The Ogowe basin and surrounding regions 23', 'content': 'To the south of Cameroon, the Ogowe basin and surrounding regions (the Woleu, Noya and Como basins to the north and the Nyanga basin to the south) correspond more or less to the modern territories of Equatorial Guinea and Gabon. Covered largely by equatorial forest, this vast area, bordering on the Congo basin to the south and east, has been inhabited by man since time immemorial, as testified by the remains of stone tools discovered during archaeological excavations conducted at various sites in Gabon some twenty years ago.
As yet, however, we know nothing about the physical characteristics or the mores and way of life of these first inhabitants of the region. Second, this was the root cause of a profound transformation of indigenous societies. The old social structure, char› acterized by blood ties and by the emergence in each clan of three social classes, namely, pure-bloods (futnu in Punu, awo-ntche in Omyene, atem bo bayong in Fang), half-castes (awoga in Omyene, mintobe in Fang) and slaves, began to be replaced by another social stratification based on wealth in which, alongside a middle and a lower class, a merchant upper middle class or bourgeoisie composed essentially of chiefs and notables, who exercised a monopoly on big business, featured prominently.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.594, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Cameroon coast and its hinterland 14', 'content': "The commercial unity of the Cameroon-Bimbia-Rio del Rey region was further enhanced by the links established by each of the sub-sections of the region with the Bamenda grasslands in the interior.$^{20}$ Thus, many of the slaves reaching the coast between 1820 and the 1840s came from the Bamenda 'grassfields' and reached Bimbia and the Cameroon river via the Rio del Rey region. But by the mid-nineteenth century, Bell Town and Bimbia traders, working together, had begun to compete successfully though peacefully with the leading traders of the Rio del Rey.

In the Cameroon river and Bimbia, as in Calabar and the Niger delta, slaves were used in producing palm oil and palm kernels and other commodities of legitimate commerce. At Bimbia and the Cameroon river, an important variation was the well-organized system by which Kings William and Bell hired out some of their slaves to the West African Company at Fernando Po. [{'id': 68, 'article_title': "CAPTAIN BURTON'S ASCENT OF THE CAMEROONS MOUNTAIN.", 'full_section_title': "CAPTAIN BURTON'S ASCENT OF THE CAMEROONS MOUNTAIN.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-22', 'issue_date': '23_12_1862', 'content': 'and boulders being loose and rolling. Seven hours had been occupied in finishing the last five miles of the ascent, and he hoped to return in three. The mercury fell to 40 deg. as he passed Mount Helen. Twilight came on, then a darkness that could be felt. He was compelled to halt. The cry of the Kroo-boy was heard at the spring, and soon firesticks marked the place of the camp. After the supper of hungry men, the party retired to rest, but not to sleep; the sun and wind had sorely burned their hands and faces, their legs ached, and spasmodic cramps seized their limbs.

A variety of expeditions followed this first exploration. Mr. Saker returned, with Mr. Robert Smith, on the 5th of January, and on the 13th he made the third ascent, and was the first to boil the thermometer upon Victoria Peak. On the 15th Mr. Saker again returned to Victoria.

A final ascent was begun on the 27th January. The night following the cold was so intense, that the mercury fell to 33 deg. 5 min. The waterproof coats of the travellers were white with hoar, and the peak was powdered with frozen dew. Before leaving the peak Captain Burton was able to discover a complete solfaterra, lying to the north-east of Albert Crater. Smoke arose in long puffy volumes from long lines of white marl and sulphur. This discovery accounts for the many detached reports of flames seen issuing from the mountain by the cloth merchants of Cameroons River and the people of Fernando Po. A hailstorm signalised the day of descent.

On the 31st January the camp at Mann's Spring was broken up. On the 2nd February the scattered bungalows of Victoria were reached, where the travellers were hospitably received by Mrs. Saker, who had purposely remained till their return.

"These lines," says Captain Burton, in conclusion, "will show the adaptability of the Cameroons Mountain for a sanitarium, a colony, or a convict station. A locale which shows every morning hoar-frost during the hot season, in a region removed but 4 degs. from the Equator, is not to be despised in the days when it is proposed to remove Calcutta to Simla. The Anglo-Scandinavian race cannot, it is true, thrive in all climates; but there are few, and those are valueless, in which choice of site could not make him a cosmopolite."

Our readers will, we are sure, be glad to receive the disinterested and most valuable testimony of this celebrated traveller to the truthfulness of all that our pages have contained of the salubrity and fitness of the vicinity of Amboises Bay for a missionary or commercial settlement. It is the very place of all places for Christian industrial colored emigrants from Canada.'}, {'id': 1657, 'article_title': 'Eruption of the Cameroons Mountain', 'full_section_title': 'Eruption of the Cameroons Mountain', 'last_edit_date': '09-08-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1869#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_10_1869', 'content': 'Sir,—The Cameroons Mountain is in eruption, after having been quiet, it is said, for several centuries. I will send you, as soon as possible, as full details as I can of this interesting event.—Yours sincerely,'}, {'id': 2917, 'article_title': 'THE EARTHQUAKE IN SOUTH AMERICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE EARTHQUAKE IN SOUTH AMERICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1875#article-7', 'issue_date': '02_08_1875', 'content': 'The New York Tribune of June 26 publishes additional information respecting the disastrous earthquake in South America, derived from private letters received by merchants doing business with the country in which the calamity took place. It says: "The locality where the earthquake occurred is the great coffee district of South America. The region affected by the shocks covers five degrees of latitude, and is 500 miles wide. The shock extended in a north-east direction along the northern range of the Andes. It was felt first very perceptibly at Bogota, the capital of New Granada, thence seemed to travel north, gathering intensity as it advanced, until it reached the south-east boundary-line of Magdalena, where the work of destruction began, continuing as it advanced along the eastern boundary of Magdalena, following the line of the mountain range, and destroying in part or whole the cities of Cucuta, San Antonio, El Bsario, Salazar, San Cristobal, San Cayetano, and Santiago. The destruction was greatest in Gramalato, Arboledas, Cúcuta, and Cucuta. Of the 14,000 persons who died from the effects of the earthquake only about 5,000 were killed outright; the remainder died in a short time from fever and lock-jaw, which in that region nearly always supervene when severe injuries have been received. The first premonition of the terrible visitation occurred on the night of May 17, when a strange rumbling sound was heard beneath the ground, although no earthquake occurred. It seemed as if a huge boulder had been propelled over the earth, causing a rattling of windows and doors and a trembling of crockery. It travelled in the direction afterwards taken by the earthquake, and lasted only a few minutes. It excited fears, which soon subsided when no serious results followed. But on the morning of May 18 a terrible shock occurred, which brought consternation to all the inhabitants of Cucuta. It suddenly shook down the walls of houses, tumbled down churches and the principal buildings, burying the citizens of the place in the ruins. Another shock completed the work of desolation by throwing down the walls that still remained standing. Three more shocks followed of equal intensity, but there appears to be no evidence that there were any openings in the earth, which on similar occasions have engulfed buildings and inhabitants, at least not in Cucuta. The shocks, with lesser force, however, seem to have been felt throughout the whole region of the earthquake for two days afterwards, extending to Cartagena and the western sea-coast. The scenes that followed the first shocks are described as being most fearful and terrible. In this hour of destruction, when men and women were praying for relief and mercy, others who had escaped immediately began an indiscriminate pillage, searching the ruins for treasure, and in many cases robbing the dying and dead. The desire for plunder was so great in some instances that the robbers murdered persons who were caught in the falling timbers, and who could not extricate themselves, though only slightly injured. The vaults of the banking-houses were penetrated, and large sums of money stolen. 'The thieves were monarchs of the ruins,' said a correspondent. Then, to add to the horror of the calamity, the Lobotera Volcano suddenly began to shoot out lava in immense quantities, or, as a correspondent writes, 'it sent out a mass of molten lava in the form of incandescent balls of fire into the city.' Some of these balls fell upon the German drug stores of Thiers and Co. and Van Diesel and Co., setting them on fire immediately. The flames communicated with the adjoining dwellings. A shower of lava set the ruins of the large city in flames while the earth was still quaking. It is probable that the next crop of coffee will suffer greatly, as the survivors cannot be induced to return to the region laid desolate, and they have become so panic-stricken that no future efforts will probably produce any effect upon them. Affairs are in a terrible state. The bodies of the dead are becoming decomposed under the tropical heat, and the stench fills the atmosphere for miles around." The earthquake is considered the most disastrous of the last two centuries. A committee of the Spanish residents of New York has been formed in that city for the purpose of affording relief to the sufferers.'}, {'id': 5410, 'article_title': 'Cable-Laying on the African Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Cable-Laying on the African Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1886#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_09_1886', 'content': 'Besides negroes and monkeys, we met sharks. The Bay of Dakar swarms with them, and one can always tell their dinnertime by watching the shoals of fish which, pursued by the sharks below, and taken by the birds above, were leaping out of the water in all directions. The most dreaded shark round there is the hammer-head. Less shy than the others, they will swim round the ship for hours, and we made many attempts to catch one, but without success. The meaning of their name is obvious when you see one. The skull has a great protuberance on each side, reaching out to a greater width than that of the body at the thickest part, so that the head resembles very much the head of a hammer, whose handle is the body. Very ferocious they are, and as their mouths reach the whole width of the hammer-head, it requires no great skill on their part to catch some part of the sailor overboard whom luck has sent. The white shark is much larger than the hammer-head, but we could only see one by dropping in an empty egg box or potato basket, which succulent dainty would often bring him up from below.

After leaving the African coast when we had done our work, we went to the Cape de Verde Islands, where is the Cable Company's office, to "inaugurate" the cables. The inauguration consisted in giving a party to the island, to which almost every one was asked. Every shade of complexion was there, from the beautiful olive of the Portuguese lady to the all but pure negress. The party was very refined. The entertainment offered was music and supper. Those who could sing, sang. The others drank whiskies and sodas in the verandah. We all had supper. The entertainment went on for a long time afterwards. I believe it was the only party that had been given on the island within the memory of man.

As to the islands, they are volcanic, and the hills rise to a great height above the sea—in some cases almost straight out of it. In these small islands two hills rise to four or five times the height of any of Europe, and are, in the north, precipitous from top to bottom. The famous Peak of Teneriffe, which is a perfectly symmetrical cone, is still an active volcano. This reaches an elevation nearly equal to the two rocks at Cape de Verde.

In leaving Cape de Verde, our work was done, and the expedition was over. Our voyage home was saddened by the death of a cable hand from sunstroke, a little south of Gibraltar. We stopped at Lisbon on our way home, and entertained a few people on board, and one day went to the King and Queen, who received us gracefully, but dismissed us without speaking to any one but the leaders.'}, {'id': 5935, 'article_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'full_section_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1889#article-7', 'issue_date': '02_12_1889', 'content': 'A letter of great interest has been received by the Royal Geographical Society from Mr. Stanley, giving some of the geographical results of his expedition.

Lieut. Stairs in June attempted to reach the summit of the snowy Ruwenzori, which Mr. Stanley assures us is identical with the "Mountains of the Moon" of the ancients. Lieut. Stairs only reached a height of 10,600 ft., progress being stopped by three deep ravines, covered with dense vegetation, that lay between them and the nearest snowy peak, which rose to a further height of 6,000 ft. The mountain sides up to 8,000 ft. are inhabited by a people who disappeared before Lieut. Stairs and his party. Bamboo forests clothe the lower mountain sides, above which was a dense growth of heaths rising to 20 ft. The night was bitterly cold, a great contrast to the valley they had left, and yet the thermometer registered 60 deg. when the party turned in for the night. The upper part of the peak before him Lieut. Stairs could see was devoid of vegetation. The top is crowned with a mass of jagged and precipitous rock, and has a distinct crater-like form. In the distance another peak could be seen having a similar form. Lieut. Stairs concludes that the Ruwenzori is really an extinct volcano; the whole having a resemblance to the mountains of Auvergne.

Mr. Stanley's own notes on the physical geography of the lake region are highly interesting. If, he says, you draw a straight line from the debouchere of the Nile from Lake Albert in a south-west direction, you measure a broad line of subsidence from twenty to fifty miles wide, in the centre of the African Continent. On the west of this is a great upland rising to 3,000 ft. To the east is another upland, rising from 1,000 ft. to 3,000 ft. and trending gently eastwards on the Unyoro plateau. In this section lies the Albert Nyanza. In the south section, only fifty miles long, lies Lake Albert Edward and the plains between the lake and the mountain. Thus, Lake Albert Edward is comparatively small, not more than half the length of the north lake. The part of the Semliki valley which extends from the lake south-westerly is very level; and, in Mr. Stanley's opinion, of recent formation. At seventy-five miles from the Albert Nyanza the valley attains a height of about 900 ft. above the lake, and then the forest region ends, and a new climate is reached.'}, {'id': 6691, 'article_title': "A Lady's Adventures in West Africa", 'full_section_title': "A Lady's Adventures in West Africa", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_01_1896', 'content': "despatched by the elephant-men. **"THE CROWN AND ITS SERVANTS."**  
COURT OF APPEAL.—Dec. 13.  
*(Before the Master of the Rolls, Lord Herschell and Lord Justice Kay.)*  
**DUNN v. THE QUEEN.**

This was an appeal from the decision of Mr. Justice Day, which was reported in *The African Times* of December 1895, p. 188. The case came before the Queen's Bench Division, on a petition of right by Edward Ernest Dunn, in which the suppliant claimed to be entitled to certain salary under an alleged contract of service for three years. In 1892 the suppliant was appointed Consular Agent in the Oil Rivers Protectorate by Sir Claude (then Major) Macdonald, her Majesty's Commissioner and Consul-General in the Protectorate. The terms on which the suppliant was appointed were said to be contained in a letter, which had since been lost, written by Sir Claude Macdonald to Major Verner, who was employed by Sir Claude to obtain fit men for the posts of Vice-Consul and of Consular Agent. One of the terms was said to be that the appointment was to be for three years certain. The suppliant was dismissed in October 1893. The Crown did not attempt to justify the dismissal, but it was contended that appointments under the Crown could only be during the pleasure of the Crown, and that Sir Claude Macdonald had no power to make an appointment for a fixed time. For the suppliant it was argued that, though with regard to military appointments the rule was as stated, there was no authority for extending it to Civil servants. Mr. Justice Day gave judgment for the Crown, and the suppliant now appealed.'}]

[{'document_title': "CAPTAIN BURTON'S ASCENT OF THE CAMEROONS MOUNTAIN.", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our readers have been made aware by our advertisements relative to a proposed emigration of Christian coloured families from Canada to Ambas (or Amboises) Bay, on the West Coast of Africa, that immediately behind the small settlement of the Baptist Missionary Society at Victoria, in that bay, there rises a magnificent mountain, more than 13,000 feet in height, and which appears to have been known to the ancients under the name of "Theon Ochema." This mountain is part of a range that has been already seen to extend some ninety miles into the interior, in a south-easterly direction. In modern times its summit had never been reached; and the statement of the ancient writer, that it exhibited flames of fire by night, has been regarded as doubtful: for although the natives of the district affirm the same thing, Europeans have never witnessed this remarkable phenomenon. All doubts of the volcanic character of the mountain are now, however, set at rest, its peak having been lately visited by Captain Burton, Her Majesty's Consul, in company with a Baptist missionary, the Rev. A. Saker, the Government botanist, Mr. Mann, and a Spanish gentleman from Fernando Po. Captain Burton is the well-known traveller in the East and among the Mormons; and it is from his report to Earl Russell that the following particulars of the ascent are derived.

Captain Burton states that only two attempts to reach the summit had been made for four centuries at least; one in 1847, by a Baptist missionary, the lamented Merrick, failed through want of water, after he had emerged from the belt of forest which covers the lower slopes of the mountain. Mr. Mann attempted it in 1860, but time failed him. It remained for the present party "to scale the glorious pinnacle which never yet felt the foot of man."

On the 18th December, 1861, all being ready, Captain Burton, with the Spaniard, entered the "lovely bay of Victoria," where he found Mr. Saker awaiting him. Mr. Mann had started in advance. Early the next morning the party set out with Mr. Johnson* as an interpreter, and several Kroomen to carry the luggage. The route lay through a noble forest of palms, acacias, African oak, and other fine timber trees, and through a country admirably adapted for cocoa, sugar, and coffee. Twice they forded the "bright little mountain stream which supplies Victoria with the purest water," passing west of Mount Henry, "a site," says Captain Burton, "which I at once fixed upon as a provisional sanitarium, to be prepared before the grand institution near the summit of the mountain."

After four hours' walking they halted for breakfast at a village of the chief Miyombi, 23,420 feet from Victoria, and 1,000 feet above the sea. The thermometer stood at 67 deg. 5 min.', 'last_edit_date': '1862-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1862#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.609, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The latest explorations confirm the earlier accounts of the volcanic character of the mountain, but the date of its activity as a volcano must have been very long ago. The lava fields are in many instances covered with grass, growing in a soil formed by disintegration of the once molten rock; and, unlike what we find in some mountains of this description, the slopes of Kilimanjaro are pastoral rather than picturesque. The melting snows coursed athwart the path taken by Dr. Meyer across the saddle connecting Kibo and Kemawenzi, the two peaks into which the mountain mass has settled. But one of the most remarkable physical facts about Kilimanjaro is that not a single stream descends its sides, except on the southern aspect. Mr. Thomson, who first observed this feature, mentions a score of rivulets, many of them of considerable size, which course through the Chaga country. Yet they all rise on the southern side of the mountain, and, joining in the plain below, form the Pangani River. The present exports came from a zone of production of not over 100 kilometres, reckoned from the coast inland. What lay beyond was as yet completely unknown. The Cameroons possessed a rich volcanic soil, which extended from Fernando Po in a north-easterly direction, and the country had also an abundance of rain, which was a point of great importance. It could not be said that there was any great mineral wealth; at least, no signs of it had thus far been detected. As elephants were very abundant there—more so than in any other part of Africa—an attempt should be made to tame them. Here there is a sudden rise of 4,000ft. Up to the country of the Bali the ground falls but little, and it then slopes away to the north-west, particularly in South Adamawa. At Takum the traveller emerges from a mountain range, which stretches from the north-east south of Yola; west of Takum extensive plains follow each other down to the Binué. The grass land in the Bali region is treeless and fairly hilly; only in the valleys of the water-courses is bush country found. In the other parts of the grass lands traversed the savanna is characterised by small trees of about 20ft. high, stunted by the grass fires. These trees at times grow so thickly that they offer a welcome shade for the otherwise sun-scorched lands of Adamawa. The river valley of the Calabar reaches right up to the foot of the West African table-land. The Katsena-allah has a north-easterly direction, and is separated from the Calabar by the border lands of the plateau regions. The mountain chains, mostly composed of crystalline slates, have a general run from south-east to north-west, with transverse valleys running north and south. The mountain outlines in the southern portion of this region are mostly roundish; but in Adamawa proper there is an abundance of sharp, jagged formations, and huge rock pyramids, cones, and crests projecting 300ft. above their surroundings continually meet the gaze. Alluvial iron ore is plentiful, and the iron industry among the Bali is in a highly developed condition. The country is poor in many places between Yola and Gashka, where the laterite and disintegrated quartz occupy extensive wastes, which vividly recall the lands bordering on the Lower Congo. The interior of the Cameroons is much poorer than East and South Africa, although not barren. The elephant is the chief characteristic of the country. Antelopes are numerous in the lowlands of the Binué; monkeys and chimpanzees are plentiful in the deserts to the south of Takum, where the tracks made by them are often very similar to the native paths, and on many occasions led the expedition astray. The abundance of domestic animals in the interior—great buffaloes, maned sheep, and fowls—is in great contrast to the poor condition of the cattle-rearing industry in the West African coast regions, and the same can be said of Adamawa. There is no special distinction between the population of the primeval forest districts and that of the grass lands, although the latter is decidedly more developed and freer; it is as if the boundlessness of the savanna reflected itself in the people inhabiting it. All the negro races in the interior of the Cameroons are fully medium-sized—indeed, among the Bali, for example, the traveller meets with well-proportioned herculean figures. In the forest regions and among the Bali clever frisure of the hair are customary; the men in Adamawa mostly have their heads clean shaven, while the women have a great preference for towering chignons. The Bali place great value upon oblong skulls and endeavour to shape the heads of newly-born children accordingly—a peculiarity which is very seldom met with in Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1890#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.631, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AND ITS TRADE POSSIBILITIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Feb. 13, an interesting lecture, entitled "A Naturalist on the Mountains of the Moon," was delivered at the Royal Institution, Liverpool, under the auspices of the Liverpool Geographical Society, by Mr. G. F. Scott Elliot. The lecture was followed with much interest as an exposition from an authority on the subject. Mr. Scott Elliot, by his recent visit to Ruwenzori, has afforded additional information about this magnificent range of mountains in Central Africa, and his treatment of the subject was graphic and most informing. The address was made the more interesting by a series of limelight views. After touching on the character of Africa generally, the lecturer proceeded to give an account of the mountain Ruwenzori, the various difficulties in climbing the primeval forest, its inhabitants, the bamboo zone, the peat mosses, and the various tribes round the mountain. The occurrence of recent volcanic craters, and the manner in which the cloud hangs over the mountain all day long, only disappearing about sunset, was fully illustrated by slides from photographs taken by the lecturer. The lecturer described his experiences. Leopards attacked his camp, and very nearly killed two of his porters. A woman was carried off by a lioness, and he vainly attempted to rescue her. Elephants were extremely abundant round the mountain. The Natives were usually friendly, though the difficulty of obtaining supplies was often considerable, and on one occasion three of his men were attacked by them, and one very severely wounded. His march to the South was one of extraordinary difficulty, as his caravan consisted only of fourteen men, and the people were in places extremely unfriendly, and on one occasion attacked his porters. The future value of these little-known regions was shown by him to depend mainly on three factors—First, the natural wild resources, as rubber, palm oil, minerals, and ivory; secondly, the prospects of plantation by Europeans; and thirdly, the health of Europeans. The country between 3,000 and 5,000 feet had been proved to be valuable for plantations of coffee and tobacco. It is only in Africa above 5,000 feet that there is any possibility of a real colony being formed. The lecturer expressed his opinion that with the knowledge we have now of these parts, the Masai Highlands certainly appear to be quite healthy enough for Europeans to live and bring up children; but that so far there is no sufficient inducement for colonisation at present. Then, turning to the needs of Great Britain at the present time, he suggested that the three main requisites at present were—first, that our imports of food and raw material should come from our own Colonies; secondly, new markets; and thirdly, an outlet for our capital and population, both of which were unnaturally locked up in Great Britain. These new countries were, according to him, exactly adapted to answer those three urgent necessities.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GOLD MINES OF THE GOLD COAST.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Although a long period has elapsed since the riches of this portion of West Africa have been known to Europeans, it is only in the last few years that the nature of its auriferous formations has been at all understood. Even now our knowledge of them is very imperfect, their thorough exploration being impeded by climatic and physiographic influences. In a country, of which the greater part of the surface consists of swamps overgrown with mangrove forests, and which is rendered impenetrable by the luxuriance of the vegetation, geological and geographical studies are rendered all but impossible, whilst the absence of mountains prevents the traveller from obtaining a clear idea of the general configuration. The surface of the country presents a series of flat swampy plains, copiously watered by rivers and streams, and intersected by chains of hills gradually increasing in elevation as we recede from the sea-coast towards the interior, the said chains of hills being, very roughly, parallel to the average trend of the coast. Having regard to the large annual rainfall (about 60 in.), to the exceeding softness of the rocks, and the great sinuosities of the river, as well as to the general surface contour, no geologist can doubt that we have here a well marked example of a low plateau, from which hills have been produced simply by subaerial denudation, the harder portions having resisted the influence of the aqueous action which has worn the softer parts into hollows and valleys. In many cases, the hills owe their existence to a quartz reef which they enclose, and which has formed the backbone of the hill; a confirmation of this theory may be found in the fact that the northern slope of the hills is usually far steeper than the southern, the enclosed reef dipping to the south. The country rock is in most cases a non-stratified and but slightly indurated clay rock, resting upon soft blue slates, at times schistose; but in the present imperfect state of our geological knowledge of this region this statement must be regarded as conjectural rather than conclusive. The writer has never himself seen a single fossil that might aid in fixing the geological epoch of this formation, nor has he ever heard of such having been found, and is disposed to regard it as modern, geologically speaking. Round the bases of these low hillocks, and covering some of the more elevated plains, are deposits of non-consolidated gravels which are occasionally auriferous. These have been and are worked by the natives, especially on the banks of the smaller streams, tributaries of the river Ancobra, which intersects and forms the main highway of communication between the various gold mining concessions and the coast. Hitherto, none of these auriferous deposits have been found sufficiently rich to repay the attention which various European explorers have directed towards them, though there is no reason why such should not be discovered, especially towards the interior. The main wealth of the region lies in its deposits of gold quartz, which have been and are now worked by various mining companies.
