(Loud applause.)—*From Report of Meeting of the Royal Geographical Society.*"}, {'id': 5224, 'article_title': 'Affairs at Stanley Pool', 'full_section_title': 'Affairs at Stanley Pool', 'last_edit_date': '07-14-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-13', 'issue_date': '01_10_1885', 'content': 'The following interesting report has been received in this country from Mr. Harry George Whitley, one of the Baptist missionaries at Stanley Pool:—

"Baptist Mission Station, Stanley Pool,  
"July 14, 1885.

"The German explorer, Weissman, who entered the country at St. Paul de Loanda, eighteen months ago, arrived yesterday, July 13, at Stanley Pool. He has traversed a large extent of country, and settled most important points. The large rivers Lulua, Sankuru, Kassai, and Lubilash, instead of flowing north and joining the Congo in its great sweep north of the Equator, all turn westward and unite in one great stream, which bears several names, but which it is safe to term the Kassai. This stream absorbs the great Kwango, and, still trending west, receives the waters flowing from Lake Leopold, and then empties itself into the Congo at a place now called Kwamonth.

"This, however, leaves certain rivers—Iruki, Lulanga, Ikelumba, and others—to be accounted for, and the only reasonable supposition is that there must be a large lake or very extensive swamp in the hollow of the northern bend of the Congo. A few months will see this point settled. The newly-discovered country is rich and fertile, the people friendly, and, what is a matter of surprise as well as of joy, not without a knowledge of religion. They believe in God who lives in the sky, who sees and knows all that they do, and they expect to go to Him when they die."

"July 31.

"I went out in the Peace steamer to meet the fleet of canoes with about 200 Balubas. These people differ a great deal from the types we are accustomed to see here. The men are mostly tall, stalwart fellows, tattooed all over, not in raised cicatrices like the Bayansi, but in fine blue lines and curves like the Fiji islanders.

"Before they came here they did not 'take much thought for their raiment,' being clothed with the scantiest of clothes, but they are better clothed now. The women are tolerably good-looking, and quite free from tattoo marks, with smooth, wholesome skins. They are jovial, sociable folks, and very curious; several are in my room at this moment, looking over my shoulder at my pen, opening all my boxes, and prying into every nook and corner in the place. Some are figuring before my mirror, vastly pleased with themselves. It is quite impossible to get rid of them; their good nature disarms any resentment one might take at their liberties, and although they have handled every article, they have stolen nothing, although they have now been here ten days or more. They have some annoying customs, however. A party will come in and repeat a few words, expecting me to answer them, every word to be repeated. This is a kindly, genial custom, doubtless, but monotonous, for the first day I had fifteen parties to oblige in this manner.'}, {'id': 5548, 'article_title': 'Central Africa and its Great Waterways', 'full_section_title': 'Central Africa and its Great Waterways', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1887#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_06_1887', 'content': 'The problem of African hydrography which Mr. Stanley hopes to solve in his Emin Pasha expedition is one of extreme importance. It is no exaggeration to say that the secret which we may expect to see disclosed will surpass in importance the discovery that the Lualaba and the Congo form one continuous waterway from the Atlantic to Lake Tanganyika. The question is whether there is not an equally mighty waterway from the same point on the Atlantic coast of Africa—the Congo mouth—right up to those southern provinces of Egypt which Gordon and his lieutenants sought to rescue from the horrors of the slave traffic, and over a portion of which Emin rules. It has been said that a shower falling over a particular area in the interior of Brazil will contribute to the waters of the North and South Atlantic, and to the Pacific. By a similar chain of rivers there is reason to believe a small shower falling in the vicinity of the Albert Nyanza would flow alike to the Mediterranean and to the Atlantic far south of the equator. In a few months we may expect to learn that the north-western half of Africa is almost an island, separated from the south-east portion by the Congo, the Mobangi, and the Nile.'}, {'id': 5548, 'article_title': 'Central Africa and its Great Waterways', 'full_section_title': 'Central Africa and its Great Waterways', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1887#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_06_1887', 'content': '

We have from time to time noted the additions made to our knowledge of the northern tributaries of the great arc of the Congo. In 1870, Dr. Schweinfurth, travelling up the Gazal, tributary of the White Nile, reached the bank of the westward-flowing Wellé, of which he had heard from the Nubians after leaving Khartoum. His feelings on seeing this river must have resembled those of Mungo Park when he first beheld the Niger. Schweinfurth surmised that the Wellé might be the upper waters of the Binúé, the important river which joins the Niger; but he inclined to the opinion that it is identical with the Shari, flowing into Lake Chad from the south-east. Dr. Junker began his explorations in 1876, and found the sources of the Makua near the Albert Nyanza. In 1880 he returned to the Makua, and explored its basin westward as far as the sareba of Ali Kobo, an Egyptian Government ivory trader. This point is north-west of Stanley Falls. Here the Makua is so colossal a stream that its width is not less than six miles. It includes innumerable islands, some of which are populated by a distinct race, known as the A-Bassongo, who monopolise its navigation, and have canoes sixty-three feet long. Others of the islands are said to be "full" of elephants. Dr. Junker learned that westward the Makua was joined by the Kuta, a river flowing from east to west further to the north, and believed to be a branch of the Mobangi. Having no means of navigating the Makua further, and as a voyage would probably have meant fighting, owing to the dissensions fomented by the slave-hunters, Dr. Junker turned back to complete Lupton Bey's surveys to the north-east. The news of the capture of Rumbeck by the Mahdi's forces induced him to retire and join Emin at Lado. He remained with Emin in the Equatorial Province on the Upper Nile until last year, when he succeeded in negotiating a passage through Uganda, and travelled to Zanzibar, which he reached at Christmas, escorted by a caravan of Tippoo-Tib's. Dr. Junker's exploration still leaves a doubt as to whither the Makua flowed, though its great width suggested that it could not possibly be the Shari. Does it turn northward to some vast lake, and send only a portion of its waters to Lake Chad? Does it continue westward to feed the Binúé and Niger system? Or does it turn southward and join the Congo? The next link in the chain was supplied by Mr. Grenfell, who, about eighteen months ago, sailed up the Mobangi to a point apparently north of the Makua. The Makua would therefore have to cross the Mobangi in order to continue a westward course. The Mobangi joins the Congo from the north at the point where the latter—if we proceed up the river from Stanley Pool—turns eastward to form its great arc. The Congo is so wide here that its northern bank is not visible from the south shore; and so wide is the Mobangi also, and so sharp the angle at which the two rivers meet, that Grenfell sailed one hundred miles up the Mobangi before he discovered he had left the Congo and was proceeding north-eastward, he knew not whither. Mr. Wills is justified in arguing that when the great size of the Makua is taken into account it seems almost certain that it is identical with Grenfell's Mobangi. There is another argument, to which Mr. Wills does not allude. On the old maps which illustrate the explorations of the Portuguese, and notably those of Lopez in 1578, the Zaire or Congo is shown, not only with a great arc resembling that on Stanley's map and fed from a lake to the south-east, but also a great north-eastern branch, the course of which is analogous to that indicated as the course of the Makua and Mobangi. And in the account of his explorations and inquiries Lopez tells us that the chief source of the Zaire is "the same lake from which the Nile flows," and that it is also fed by a lake "formed by the Nile." These observations are suggestive of the hydrography of the Mutá Nzige and Albert Nyanza region.'}, {'id': 5835, 'article_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'full_section_title': "Geographical Results of Mr. Stanley's Expedition", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-9', 'issue_date': '06_05_1889', 'content': 'Mr. Stanley has addressed an interesting letter to the secretary of the Royal Geographical Society, in which the explorer enters minutely into the geographical results of his expedition, into the character and relations of the different tribes met with, and the nature of the products of one of the most remarkable countries of Africa. "Until we penetrated and marched through it, this region was entirely unexplored and untrodden by either white or Arab." His description of some characteristics of the forest which had to be penetrated is worth quoting. The difficulties "consisted of creepers ranging from 6in. to 15in. in diameter, swinging across the path in bowlines or loops, sometimes massed and twisted together; also of a low dense bush, occupying the sites of old clearings, which had to be carved through before a passage was possible. Where years had elapsed since the clearings had been abandoned, we found a young forest and the spaces between the trees choked with climbing plants, vegetable creepers, and tall plants. This kind had to be tunnelled through before an inch of progress could be made." This is the forest through which Livingstone struggled his way in the Manyuema country in the months before Stanley relieved him. Mr. Stanley shows that the region traversed by him is probably the most extensive forest region in Africa, a region resembling the forest region of South America. Mr. Stanley has definitely settled the courses of an important affluent of the Congo and its tributaries; he has defined the southern limits of the Albert Nyanza, and found that it is rapidly decreasing; he has all but established the fact of the existence of a separate lake to the south, which probably drains into the Congo and not into the Nile; and no doubt on his return he will tell us more of the snowy mountain rivalling Kilimanjaro, far away to the south-east of his standpoint on the west shore of Albert Nyanza. It seems clear that the natural outlet of the region around Albert Nyanza is not by the Aruwimi, but eastwards by Victoria Nyanza and British East Africa. The following extract from Mr. Stanley's letter will afford a fair idea of some of the geographical results:—

The Aruwimi has many names—the Dudu, Biyerre, Luhali, the Nevva, Nowelle-Itiré. For the last 300 miles of its course, but upward to its source, it has a singular, wide-spreading fame under the name of Ituri. The aborigines of the Nyanza, the open plateau and forest tribes down to within a few miles of the Kepoko, all unite in calling it the Ituri.'}]

These observations are suggestive of the hydrography of the Mutá Nzige and Albert Nyanza region.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1887#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Congo Region and its Great Waterways', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The detailed accounts of Lieutenant Wissmann's recent explorations in that portion of the Congo basin which lies within the bend of the river will necessitate further important modifications in our maps of the hydrography of the African interior. Hitherto the rivers of the southern portion of the Congo basin have been supposed to run from south to north, and are thus represented on all recent maps, including those of the International Association and the map in Stanley's latest book. The latest explorer, Wissmann, however, has found that they run rather in an east to west direction. It is noteworthy that his discoveries confirm in several respects the hydrography of Cameron's map, some of the details of which will have to be restored to the place from which they have lately been erased. To this portion of the Congo basin German explorers have given special attention. In 1870 Pogge and Buchner succeeded in establishing friendly relations with the King of Lunda, the region lying to the east of Angola and now included in the Congo Free State. Subsequently Pogge and Wissmann founded a station in the Mukenge territory, near the upper waters of the Kassai, a considerable river apparently flowing northward, and supposed to be the Buruki Mohindu, or Black River, which falls into the Congo at Equator Station. Wissmann returned to Germany in 1883, but next year was sent out by the International Association. Landing at Loanda, he started for the interior via Malange. Here he met Pogge, who was returning sick to the coast, where he shortly afterwards died. In July, Wissmann continued his journey with a force of 500 men, and crossing the Kuango (now an important highway for Portuguese trade), succeeded in reaching Mukenge Station. After spending some time here to await the arrival of an expedition sent from the German African Society under Lieutenant Schulz, he launched his steel boat on the Kassai, and proceeded on a northward voyage; but, to his astonishment, he found the river suddenly turned to the west. No hindrance to navigation presented itself, and eventually he entered the Congo at Kwamouth Station, a little above Stanley Pool, instead of at Equator Station, about 250 miles further north. At the point where the Kassai turned westward he found it received a great river, which he identified as the Sankuru, the river previously met with in the neighbourhood of Nyangwe, far to the east, and which is actually visited from the East Coast by Arab traders and slave dealers. Moreover, in due time he came upon a great lake, which, by the light of his newly acquired knowledge, he identified as the Lake Sankuru of Cameron, and the Lake Leopold of Stanley. Thus the Sankuru, flowing west from the neighbourhood of Nyangwe, with its continuation the Kassai, forms a great east and west watercourse connecting the neighbourhood of Stanley Pool with the vicinity of Lake Tanganyika. On Stanley's map the Kassai and the Sankuru appear as two distinct rivers, running from south to north, and falling into the Congo north of the equator—the former, as already stated, near Equator Station, and the latter far to the east, in the vicinity of Stanley Falls. On Cameron's map the general direction is correctly shown, and the latitude also is approximately correct; the Sankuru, however, appears as the Lualaba, and the lake of that name is placed too much to the east. Further surprises may yet be in store for us, and it would therefore be hasty to assume that other approximations to Cameron's map and nomenclature may not be necessary.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CONGO FREE STATE', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Mobangi, Losaka, Loika, and Maringa rivers, besides other smaller tributaries of the Congo; thus extending our knowledge in various directions for a distance of at least 1,500 miles. As an account of these discoveries has already been published, I shall allude to them very briefly. The most important of these rivers is the Mobangi. Mr. Grenfell ascended it as far as 4° 30' N. latitude. As he proceeded northward, he perceived certain differences in the natives, as compared with those he was accustomed to on the Congo. These latter are known by the generic name of Bantu, while the Mobangi native appeared to have characteristics similar to the natives of the Cameroons and the Gold Coast, which properly belong to the Fan tribe. As these rivers are explored, and the border lands of these two great nations, the Bantu and Fan, become better known, an interesting study will be afforded to the ethnologist. A little beyond 4° N. lat., Mr. Grenfell had to return, but not before he had ascertained that the course of the Mobangi tended to the eastward. Now the size and the volume of this tributary of the Congo prove it the offspring of many waters, while its direction points that it may have its origin in the Niam-Niam and Mangbattu countries; in fact, that it is the Makua or Welle of Schweinfurth. It is always satisfactory when the disjointed discoveries of a great river are connected by a complete survey, and the unknown becomes the known. Let us hope this will soon be the case with the Mobangi, and whether it proves to be the Welle, or whether it has its origin in the territory lying to the north of the Congo, either problem will be most interesting from a geographical point of view, for if the former, it will complete the work begun by Schweinfurth; if the latter, it will add to our knowledge a portion of Africa hitherto unexplored.

A German expedition under the auspices of the Berlin Geographical Society, composed of Lieuts. Schmidt, Kauntz, and Dr. Buchler, reached the Congo in the autumn of 1884. Since their arrival, they have been at work in the country between Stanley Pool, San Salvador, and the Quango. Dr. Buchler, striking the Quango near *Matundo*, followed the unexplored portion of that river to its junction with the Kasai, and thus arrived at Kimpopo, at the upper end of Stanley Pool. At one place his little party were threatened by a hostile demonstration, but when the natives learned that he was going to Bula Matari, their opposition ceased, and he was allowed to pass on without molestation.

In addition to these efforts, mention should be made of the work done in the Ogowé basin and in the country north of that river by the French, and I have no doubt M. de Brazza will shortly furnish information on this subject.", 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'An Expedition to the Sources of the Congo', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Congo Commercial Company, who have already done much to open up the Upper river and its affluents, have decided to send out a fresh expedition for the purpose of attempting the solution of the remaining problems connected with the remote feeders of the great river. A glance at a map will show that towards the south-east the territories of the Congo Free State are bounded on the east by three lakes—Tanganyika, Moero, and Bangweolo—and dotted from south to north by a series of smaller lakes among which are those of Lohemba and Upamba. These latter lakes, more or less conjectural, seem to constitute the reservoirs of the Congo. The main stream is formed, so far as is known at present, of three main branches: (1) the Lualaba, which some regard as the principal, and which comes from the south-west, forming on the map a chain of lakelets, of which only two have been seen—by Cameron and Reichard; (2) the Luapula, of which the Chambesi is the upper course, and which traverses Lakes Bangweolo and Moero, discovered by Livingstone; (3) the Lukuga, which issues from Lake Tanganyika and flows direct westwards. According to information obtained from natives and Arab traders, these three rivers unite at a common centre, where the waters form a large lake, known as Lanji, which no white traveller has seen. The country of Urua, on the west of Tanganyika, into which the expedition will penetrate, has just been touched by one or two explorers. Among them are Capello and Ivens, Reichard and Arnot, all of whom speak in glowing terms of the fertility of the region, of its salubrity, and its richness in minerals. It lies so high and is so cold sometimes as almost to freeze. It is a region on which it is desirable to have full information, in the interests of both commerce and geography. It has been stated that Mr. Stanley is likely in the future to undertake a special mission to the Upper Congo. However that may be, it is to be hoped that the Congo Company will carry out their intentions; there is plenty of room here for several expeditions. The proposed expedition will be under the command of M. Alexandre Delcommune, who has already done good work in exploring some of the Congo tributaries, and has been seventeen years on the river. He will be accompanied by Lieut. Hackanson, of the Swedish army, formerly one of the agents of the Congo Free State; Dr. Briart; Lieut. Santsschoff, formerly of the Russian army; Baron Marcel de Roert; M. Norbert Didderich, an engineer; and M. Protsch. MM. Hackanson, Briart, and Santsschoff have already sailed; M. Delcommune leaves on July 6; and M. Didderich on the 3rd. The escort will consist of 150 native soldiers. The expedition will meet at Kiachassa about the middle of September, and embarking on the steamer Roi des Belges, will proceed by the Upper Congo and its tributary, the Lomami, to the limit of navigation on the latter river, nearly opposite Nyangwé. Thence the expedition will proceed on foot. It will be absent from twelve to eighteen months.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. STANLEY AND THE CONGO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A paper was read, on February 25, at the University of London by Sir Francis De Winton, on the subject of Explorations in the Welle-Mobangi River, from the Congo, by Captain Vangele.

Sir Francis said the effect of the paper was to prove that the Welle and the Mobangi were one and the same river. The river Welle was first discovered in 1870, by Dr. Schweinfurth, on his journey to the Niam-Niam country. The Ubangi, or Mobangi, was first seen by Captain Haussens, in 1884, and after the exploration of the river in 1885-86, by Mr. Grenfell, M. Wauters started the theory of the two rivers being one and the same. On October 13, 1886, Captain Vangele entered the Ubangi in a flat-bottomed scale, and on the next day came in view of the French post, Kundja. Having described the country traversed from this point by the explorer, he said the hostility of the Yakomas made it impossible for him to proceed as far as the Falls of Kissanghi, and the party reached Leopoldville on February 13 last year. Subsequently, at the request of the Governor-General, Captain Vangele proceeded to Stanley Falls with an expedition, which had been for the time being delayed by the Commander, Captain Vandevelde.

Sir George Bowen inquired for the latest news from Stanley, and where he is now supposed to be. If an answer could be returned to his query many of them would be very much obliged.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Trade with the Congo', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Since 1886, further explorations have added 3,000 more kilometres (a kilometre is about three-fifths of a mile) to the navigable watercourse, and the news conveyed by the last despatch to King Leopold gives particulars of a new tributary which promises to open up a country exceeding in the richness of its products all other parts of the Congo State—a country likely to become the centre of European activity in tropical Africa. It has hitherto been supposed that Stanley Falls formed the extreme limit of practical communication with Central Africa. The Lomami, which joins the Congo very near the Falls, had as yet only been explored for a short distance by Grenfell. Wissmann had certainly crossed it higher up at a navigable point, but it still remained a question whether it was uninterruptedly navigable as far as this point. If it was so, the Lomami, running in about the same direction as the Congo itself above the Falls, would evidently become the highway to the area called Katanga and Ouroua, inaccessible by the Congo itself owing to the 75 miles of cataracts which bar communication beyond the Falls. Katanga is a country rich in mineral resources; copper and gold appear to abound. Its high level, moreover, renders it habitable for Europeans. hh: Ancient civilizations and powerful centers in North Africa, including Egypt and Rome, had limited cultural and intellectual influence on the interior regions of the continent.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles provide a nuanced perspective on the claim regarding the limited cultural and intellectual influence of ancient North African civilizations, such as Egypt and Rome, on the interior regions of the continent. The textbook does not directly address this claim but highlights the dynamic cultural exchanges in North Africa during the colonial period and the nineteenth century, focusing on Egypt's literary renaissance and the influence of Western and Islamic cultures. It mentions the migration of intellectuals and the establishment of educational institutions, contributing to a modern Arabic culture, but does not specifically discuss ancient influences on the interior regions. In contrast, The African Times articles support the claim by noting that despite the flourishing arts and sciences in Egypt and the establishment of military and commercial power in North Africa, these influences did not penetrate far into the interior. The Roman Empire's communication with regions like Fezzan and Nubia was limited, and Christianity's spread across North Africa did not significantly impact central, western, or southern parts of the continent. The articles also highlight that the Arab invasion and the spread of Islam had a more profound effect on Central Africa, suggesting that earlier civilizations did not achieve similar penetration. Additionally, the Phoenicians, Greeks, and Carthaginians engaged in commerce along the Mediterranean coast but did not venture far inland. Together, these observations suggest that while North Africa experienced significant cultural exchanges, the ancient civilizations' influence was largely confined to the coastal and northern regions, with limited impact on the continent's interior.

[{'id': 480, 'article_title': 'THE TIMES ON AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE TIMES ON AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-19', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': 'In editorial comments on Earl Russell's speech at Aberdeen, the *Times* says:—

"There could hardly be a more crucial test of a sanguine belief in human destiny than a confidence in the civilization of Africa. From time immemorial that vast continent has been the darkest spot in the habitable world, for neither the influence of Egypt on the East, nor that of the Roman province on the North, penetrated far into the interior. We have no reason to suppose that Africa was ever a happier country than it is now, and what it is now—how distracted with incessant wars, how desolated by famines and pestilences, how full of cruelty—may be learnt from the pages of recent travellers. The elevation of Africa to the level, we will not say of Europe or America, but of Asia, would be no restoration, but the extrication, as it were, of a new tract from the great deep. *It has been predicted, indeed, but only as communication with some neighbouring planet might be predicted.* At the same time it must be owned that to despair of improving the lot of Africa is to despair of making one community of the whole human race, even for commercial purposes. Now, if we are to build castles in the air at all, we must not stop short of this ideal. What appears certain is, that the march of civilization cannot be carried much further without overspreading Africa. Whether the African races will develop capacities the very germs of which physiologists doubt their possessing, or whether they will fill a subordinate place in a society yet to be organised, Lord Russell himself forbears to inquire, and we shall not venture to go beyond him.'}, {'id': 5969, 'article_title': 'THE AFRICAN PROBLEM', 'full_section_title': 'THE AFRICAN PROBLEM', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_04_1890', 'content': 'The world outside of Africa has not yet stopped to consider the peculiar conditions which lift that continent out of the range of the ordinary agencies by which Europe has been able to occupy other countries. They have not stopped to ponder the lessons on this subject scattered through the pages of history. Perhaps in no country is it so necessary that the stranger or newcomer should possess the sound mind in sound body; for the climate is most searching, bringing to the surface any and every latent physical or mental defect. If a man has any chronic or hereditary disease it is sure to be developed, and if wrong medical treatment is applied it often proves fatal. And as with the body so with the mind. The Negro immigrant from a temperate region sometimes suffers from climatic inconveniences, only after a brief process of acclimatisation, he becomes himself again, while the white man never regains his soundness and retains his mental equilibrium only by visits to his native climate.

When we come into the moral and intellectual world it would seem as if the Almighty several times attempted to introduce the foreigner and a foreign civilisation into Africa and then changed His purpose. For thousands of years the northeastern portions of Africa witnessed a wonderful development of civilisation. The arts and sciences flourished in Egypt, and that country was the centre of universal influence; but no effect was produced upon the interior. North Africa became the seat of a great military and commercial power which flourished for 700 years. After this the Church constructed a mighty influence in the same region, but the interior of the continent received no impression from it.'}, {'id': 6098, 'article_title': 'THE PARTITION OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE PARTITION OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '04-07-1891', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1891#article-11', 'issue_date': '04_05_1891', 'content': 'most advanced of the Native States of the African continent, whose territory had been the prey of outside Powers, and he showed that the dawn of African exploration and partition commenced with the Phoenicians, who navigated the Mediterranean for an unknown period, and founded the city of Utica about 1,100 B.C., nearly 300 years before the foundation of Carthage. The Phoenicians treated the part of Africa which they colonised as the British would, as the foundation of trade and commerce. The Phoenicians were followed, about 650 B.C., by the Greeks, who founded their first African colony Cyrene, on the coast of Tripoli. Then came the Carthaginians. They and the Greeks carried on a busy commerce all along the Mediterranean coast, far down to the Atlantic coast, to the mouth of the Red Sea. These were followed by the Romans, who continued an active career on the African coast until the decay of the Roman Empire.

Mr. Scott Keltie showed how little was known of the interior of Africa up to 150 A.D. by Ptolemy's map being thrown on to the sheet in the darkened theatre. This map, which was filled up haphazard fashion, gathered up, the lecturer said, all the knowledge of the continent which had accumulated during this long period of commercial activity — a knowledge which amounted to very little beyond the coasts and the Nile Valley. The next important period dealt with was the period of Arab invasion and the spread of the tenets of Mohammedanism — namely, from the seventh to the fifteenth century. In the early part of the fifteenth century commenced the "glorious" period of Portuguese activity, which lasted for some sixty years, during which the contour of the coast of Africa was completely laid down. This began the real modern partition of Africa, and the lecturer dwelt upon the effect which could be traced to Portuguese occupation of African territory — that occupation being marked by ruin rather than by enterprise. He rapidly traced the occupation of points of territory by Portuguese, Spanish, French, English, Dutch, Danish, and Germans, whose commerce was in ivory and slaves. He held that the opening up of the continent of Africa might be said to have begun with Bruce's travels in Abyssinia in the latter part of the eighteenth century. From that time until 1850 nearly the whole map of Africa became gradually filled up, and from 1850 down to the present day the southern half of the continent had received increasing attention at the hands of explorers until it also had had its main features laid down. He referred in warm terms to the discoveries of Burton, Livingstone, and Stanley.'}]

[{'document_title': 'The Introduction and Progress of Mohammedanism in Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Beyond the limits of their own empire the Romans had little communication with any people except the inhabitants of Fezzan and Nubia, and at a very late period with Abyssinia or the kingdom of Axum. Nor did Christianity seem to have extended her light far toward the centre, west or south of Egypt. Her benefits, spread over the north, disappeared here under the effects of disastrous wars. To Mohammedanism was reserved the task of effecting a change in Central Africa. The fanatic Arab mounted on the active dromedary, or embarked in light vessels, flew to plant the standard of his Prophet on the banks of Senegal and on the shores of Sofala. No people ever possessed such qualifications for conquering and preserving the empire of Africa. Among the Mauritanians and Numidians they found natural friends and brothers, and identity of manners, food, and genial climate. The fanatic Mussulman spirit astonished and subdued the ardent imaginations of the Africans; the simplicity of their creed suited their limited intellect, and easily connected itself with the superstition of fetishism, and the ideas which these people entertained of magic and enchantments. Civil slavery and despotic government suffered no change, except that the Maraboots, or Mussulman priests, and the shorifs, or descendants of the Prophet, formed in some of the states a species of aristocracy. Cannibalism was alone abolished. One event for a moment favoured the civilisation of the Moors—the expulsion of those of their number who had ruled in Spain, peopled Barbary, and even the oasis of the great desert with a more industrious and better-informed race than the rest of the Mohammedans. But unhappily for Africa, a handful of Turkish adventurers, vying with one another in ferocity and ignorance, established themselves on the coast of Barbary, subdued the Moors, and founded the barbarous governments of Algiers, Tunis, and Tripoli, forming a deadly barrier to the civilised world, more efficient than Mohammedanism itself.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1866#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN PROBLEM', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the fifteenth century the Congo country was the scene of extensive operations. Just a little before the discovery of America thousands of the natives of the Congo were baptised by Catholic missionaries, and the Portuguese devoted themselves to the work of African evangelisation and exploration. They knew then as much of interior Africa as is known now after the great exploits of Livingstone and Stanley. There is a map in the Vatican, 300 years old, which gives the general physical relief and the river and lake systems of Africa with more or less accuracy; but the Arab geographers of a century before had described the mountain system, the great lakes, and the course of the Nile. Just about the time that Portugal was establishing a great empire on that continent, America was discovered, and it became the seat of Portuguese Power. Neither Egyptian, Carthaginian, Persian, or Roman influence was allowed to establish itself on that continent. It would seem that no solution of the African problem was to come from alien sources. Africans were not to share the fate of other dark races who have come in contact with the European. Europe was diverted to the Western Hemisphere. The energies of that conquering race were spent in building up a home for themselves on this side. Africa followed in chains.

The Negro race was to be preserved for a special work in the future. It is probable that if foreign races had been allowed to enter their country they would have been destroyed. So they were brought over to be helpers in America and at the same time to be preserved. Slavery would seem to be a strange school in which to preserve a people; but God has a way of salting as well as purifying by fire. The Europeans found in America an aboriginal race unable to co-operate with them in the labours required for the construction of the new civilisation. The Indians would not work, and have suffered the consequences of that indisposition: they have passed away. To take their place as accessories in the work to be done, the African was brought, who could work and would work, and could endure the climatic conditions of a new southern country, which Europeans could not. If Europe brought the Negro, Africa furnished the hands for the work which has been achieved. But when the new continent was opened Africa was closed. The veil, which was being drawn aside, was replaced, and darkness enveloped the land.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.575, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The other day we took up a useful little work called "The Statesman's Year Book," professing to give a compact statistical account of the various states and governments of the world. Our purpose was to see what was said of Africa, the land we live in. Imagine our chagrin on finding the existence of that by no means petty continent quietly but totally ignored. Much space was, of course, accorded to the states of Europe, and the rest of the volume had reference to states not in Europe; but among these was not Africa. America, Asia, and Australia each receive a fair measure of attention, but this vast African land—although it occupies a fourth of the area of the habitable earth—although its history is older than that of any part of Europe, and its population is a ninth part of mankind—does not even come within the category of outside states—has no recognised standing—remains still a blank on the muster roll of nations. Why should this be? Why should Africa be, even in this latest age, so much a myth—so utterly obscure and unimportant—that it can be thus passed by? In old times, as far back as history reaches, the northern shores of this continent were the seats of empires that dominated the world, but now the sceptre is no longer held, the name evokes no sentiment but pity; the gloom of mystery and ignorance invests the land, and the great current of civilization as it sweeps with hastening impulse round the world, would never leave a trace upon its shores, were not stray eddies sometimes caught and kept by a few points like these.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.576, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The other day we took up a useful little work called "The Statesman's Year Book," professing to give a compact statistical account of the various states and governments of the world. Our purpose was to see what was said of Africa, the land we live in. Imagine our chagrin on finding the existence of that by no means petty continent quietly but totally ignored. Much space was, of course, accorded to the states of Europe, and the rest of the volume had reference to states not in Europe; but among these was not Africa. America, Asia, and Australia each receive a fair measure of attention, but this vast African land—although it occupies a fourth of the area of the habitable earth—although its history is older than that of any part of Europe, and its population is a ninth part of mankind—does not even come within the category of outside states—has no recognised standing—remains still a blank on the muster roll of nations. Why should this be? Why should Africa be, even in this latest age, so much a myth—so utterly obscure and unimportant—that it can be thus passed by? In old times, as far back as history reaches, the northern shores of this continent were the seats of empires that dominated the world, but now the sceptre is no longer held, the name evokes no sentiment but pity; the gloom of mystery and ignorance invests the land, and the great current of civilization as it sweeps with hastening impulse round the world, would never leave a trace upon its shores, were not stray eddies sometimes caught and kept by a few points like these.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.585, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "But amidst the obscurity that surrounds everything that is African, the signs of change are many and manifest. Never yet has the future of Africa been so full of hope and light. Here, too, there is a north and a south struggling—not for supremacy over each other, but for the regeneration of a continent. In Algeria the French are fast displacing the torpid vestiges of Moorish sway, and are transforming a fertile and healthful country into a lesser France. Where the Moslem, for five centuries, forbade Christian foot to land—where, under the cold shade of the crescent, man has so long wrapt the earth in lethargy—not far from where heathenism crouched under Carthaginian ramparts—on the very spot where a power that imperilled Europe and conquered Spain, held rule thereafter—a prosperous Christian community, great in every element of strength, is now established. Within twenty years this French colony has so grown and prospered, that it is now the home of 200,000 Europeans, consumes seven millions sterling of imports, and ships three millions sterling in the form of exports, such as corn, tobacco, cattle, fruit, oil, and minerals. That the French influence in Algeria is for good, cannot we think be disputed. From the coast to the confines of the Sahara that vigorous and vivacious people are imparting to North Africa quite a different character, and are literally making the wilderness blossom like the rose. But a yet more interesting work goes on in Egypt. Capital is flowing there from Western Europe in marvellous measure. Vast have been the benefits and the material wealth secured to Egypt by the fact of its being the highway to the East, they are as nothing compared with the blessings that are about to be conferred on it by the interposition of foreign influence, and the growing discernment and wider knowledge of those who rule Egypt. Possessed of a soil of perennial richness, calling for little culture, and naturally irrigated, the valley of the Nile, which is as prolific now as it was in Pharaoh's time, is already yielding largely in cotton and corn. Tenacious though the people may be of old customs and traditions, much of their dogged Orientalism is breaking down before the resistless forces of the age—the constant friction caused by the ever-flowing stream of western life that permeates Egypt. We say nothing of the gigantic canal scheme, which, whether it fails or succeeds—and in the interests of our common progress we hope for the latter—has enriched Egypt by the expenditure in it of millions of money. Until the Moslemised Arabs took it in hand there was no evidence that any enterprising peoples had crossed the Sahara, or, indeed, had ever gone beyond hail of the coast, except along the Nile Valley. It was only 460 years ago that Europe set herself to define the contour of the African coast. It was just about a century since Europe seriously set herself to the task of exploring the northern half of that continent and of discovering the course of the great River Niger. The Nile source was only reached some thirty-four years ago, and during the past thirty years more had been done to spread a knowledge of the continent than during the 3,800 years before. This central portion of the African continent, although it was inhabited by large masses of the population, its history was contained in the memory of the oldest inhabitants. The only reliable history was that which science revealed by the light of knowledge, and science had to solve the question whether the vast tract of country in Central Africa had any features to show that at one time the place was peopled by a large and civilised race.

Proceeding to trace the earliest recorded maps of Africa, the lecturer said that that of Herodotus, published four centuries before Christ, was followed early in the second century by that of Claudius Ptolemy. The next recorded map came a thousand years afterwards, and was a ridiculous effort. LENZ'S JOURNEY ACROSS AFRICA.", 'section_title': '', 'content': "The return of Dr. Oscar Lenz to Europe after a journey of unusually short duration from the mouth of the Congo to the mouth of the Zambesi is a notable event in the annals of African travel. Africa is gradually yielding up its secrets. The Congo now affords access to its inmost recesses, and the light of civilization is beginning to penetrate the darkest corners of the continent. Unlike most of his predecessors in the task of crossing Africa from sea to sea, Dr. Lenz has never been for any length of time cut off from communication with Europe. Either along the Congo or by means of the Arab traders, Dr. Lenz has been able to send home letters describing the several stages of his journey. The district traversed by him is no longer in the barbarous and savage condition in which Mr. Stanley found it only a few years ago. The native tribes have receded before the advance of European settlements from the Western coast, and the Arab trading establishments from the Eastern, and a form of civilization greatly in advance of anything which the native tribes could exhibit has been established in a region which in Livingstone's time was unknown and impenetrable to the outer world. Dr. Lenz's journey was accomplished throughout without the necessity having once arisen for the use of fire-arms in self-defence against any human being. It must not of course be inferred from this that Central Africa is in all respects a safe place for an unarmed traveller to venture in. Dr. Lenz's route followed the track of advancing civilization, and traversed regions which are comparatively well known. He did not find it possible to communicate with or to reach Dr. Junker and Emin Bey, or to explore the region between the Middle Congo and the Upper Nile. The houses are constructed of brick and the trunks of palm-trees, sometimes only of earth, with the result that many of them fall in ruins. There are five mosques, the principal of which has a pretty minaret in the Moorish style. Gafsa is the ancient Capsa in Numidia, of which Sallust speaks. Jugurtha fortified it, and there hid his treasures. Marius destroyed the city and its walls, which were said to have a supernatural origin. The Caid lives in a house built upon the ruins of the Roman warm baths, the only remains besides a gateway, of the ancient Capsa. The water still flows from three sources, which uniting become a stream worthy the name of river, to which the oasis is indebted for its fertility. The wealth of the people consists entirely of date-palms, planted from six to seven feet apart in parallel lines along the banks of the irrigation canals. The descendants of the Arabs were nomadic, and wandered from place to place with their flocks. These might be called the first class, and were, as a rule, the masters of the country. The second class were the descendants of the Berbers, the ancient possessors of the country; who were now subject to their Arab conquerors, to whom they paid tribute for protection. The Berbers lived in towns and villages, and were devoted to trade. The manners and customs of the Arab and Berber tribes were very similar. In physique the men were tall, well proportioned, and vigorous, graceful in their movements, and capable of enduring great hardships and fatigue. As a rule, they were good-looking, with fine eyes and teeth, and well-shaped noses and mouths. Of late there had been an admixture of negro blood, and it appeared to be on the increase. The women were by no means beautiful. The more of the Koran they knew the more devout they were considered; goodness did not necessarily come from the heart, but was the expression of the lips. They were the dupes of the "holy man," who plundered them and presumed on their ignorance and fanaticism. The Koran and a book called "Daleel el chariat" ("Guide to Goodness") were the only books they had. Kheruan, Kairouan, or Kahiruan, "the most holy place" of the "Gharb," or Mahomedan West, was selected by the Prophet himself, according to the legend, as the possible future centre of Islam. In the event of the holy city of the East being threatened by the infidels, the faithful were to flee to Kheruan with the sacred relics, and it was to take the place of Mecca as the goal of Mahomedan pilgrimage. That day of need has not yet arrived, and it is probable, in spite of the darker anticipations of Mahomed, that Islam will lose Kheruan long before it loses Mecca. Kheruan was the ancient Roman _Vicus Augusti_, which Sidi-Okba-ben-Nafa in the year 672 made his chief bulwark in his conquests in North Africa, and from which Tarik set forth in 707 for the conquest of Spain. Several of the Mahomedan dynasties which have ruled from time to time in North Africa have founded their mosques in Kheruan. In the middle of the holy city lies the grave of Sidi-el-Waib, the Prophet’s barber, and the roof of the great mosque which surrounds his tomb is upheld by more than 500 marble columns. The building was erected from stones taken from the old Roman city, and Roman inscriptions are still legible upon them here and there. The walls around Kheruan are still in a state of good preservation; its streets are broader than those of Tunis, and it has rich bazaars. Many Mahomedans retire to Kheruan in order that they may die in the holy city, and also, it is said, in order to enjoy the privilege of being free from taxation, which is accorded to every Mahomedan resident. The pilgrims who visit the place usually stay for a very long period, and spend much money, so that the population is unusually wealthy. The Arabs have bound themselves by a solemn religious vow to defend the place against the French infidel to the last extremity.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1881#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.584, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Despite perceptions of laziness and warlike tendencies, the Soninkees significantly contribute to the local economy through agriculture, while their complex spiritual practices and cultural divergence from wealth-focused societies highlight a unique societal structure.
result: The examination of the Soninkees through the lens of both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles presents a multifaceted perspective on their societal role and cultural practices. The General History of Africa does not specifically address the Soninkees, their agricultural contributions, or their spiritual practices, instead focusing on the broader complexity and diversity of African societies, which provides a contextual backdrop for understanding the Soninkees' potential economic and cultural roles. In contrast, The African Times offers a more direct, albeit mixed, portrayal of the Soninkees. The articles acknowledge their involvement in agriculture, suggesting some level of economic contribution, yet they also emphasize perceptions of laziness and a warlike nature, which complicates the narrative of significant economic impact. Furthermore, the Soninkees are described as living in simple huts and not prioritizing wealth, aligning with the claim of cultural divergence from wealth-focused societies. Their spiritual practices, such as worshiping alligators and stones and performing human sacrifices, underscore a complex spiritual structure, partially supporting the claim of a unique societal framework. Thus, while the textbook provides a general context, the news articles offer specific insights that both support and challenge the claim regarding the Soninkees' economic and cultural contributions.

[{'document_title': 'Africa at the beginning of the nineteenth century: issues and prospects', 'section_title': 'Agricultural systems', 'content': "Again, while we hardly need to emphasize the variety of patterns of production in different ecological zones of Africa - in the details of landholding and inheritance, the basic tools of farming, the crops planted, the land use, division of labour between men and women, specialization between one community and another in terms of crops, crop-farming and animal husbandry, etc. - there is another feature of the Tunisian experience relevant to Africa as a whole. If they left the emirate where they had rights to office, these rights were not transferred to their place of exile, though they might retain their title as a courtesy. By comparison, ordinary people were free to move from emirate to emirate, and did so if they felt excessively oppressed. [{'id': 486, 'article_title': "RIVER GAMBIA: MAHABA'S AFFAIRS", 'full_section_title': "RIVER GAMBIA: MAHABA'S AFFAIRS", 'last_edit_date': '11-10-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_12_1864', 'content': "Sir,—I have read the document published in your paper about Mahaba. His worshippers seem to have forgotten what atrocities he had committed. The reason why they are opposed to the Soninkee Government was, that at certain times the people generally came to the factors and begged or demanded certain articles from them, and if refused in an obstinate manner, they considered it an insult to them, as the factors were occupying the ground of their fathers. The affray then generally terminated by the traders receiving a good flogging, and being made to pay a larger demand. I do not wonder at this being complained of; but if the traders were polite and obliging to them, and showed them that the goods did not really belong to the traders, at the same time making them small presents, they generally returned double the amount in a few days in cattle.

When Badiboo was under the Soninkee Government, traders from every part of the country came down to trade in it, as it is situated near the large and populous kingdom of Salom. At Badiboo are the best cotton and phangs, numerous bandy cloth, and an immense quantity of ground-nuts; so much so, that Badiboo, under the government of the Soninkees, produced more nuts than any other kingdom on the River Gambia. The principal ground-nut marts were Swarak, Cindah, Bany, Kintak Cundah, and Sabaj. In these towns kola are sold in great abundance for phangs, and afterwards exchanged for ground-nuts, from which the petty traders derive great benefit.

The people at Badiboo are an intermixture of Jollof, Mandigo, and Foolahs, and from them the people at Bathurst receive yearly several head of cattle, with some fresh butter, corn, and rice. Although the Soninkees are universally considered to be lazy, yet still the lower class are hard-working, and when a Soninkee chief has rule over Marabouts, it is his general practice to compel them to work, so as to pay him a portion of their earnings. But when Mahaba became chief, trade almost ceased, the people in the interior being afraid to come down, as their property would not be secured from the ravages of Mahaba's people. The Cabuncas, who occupy an extensive region in the interior of Badiboo, reaching to Rio Nunez, on the other hand, were in the habit of coming down by land to Tenderbar, and from there cross over to Badiboo for the express purpose of purchasing horses and phangs, but they have since been afraid to do so."}, {'id': 591, 'article_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'full_section_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '03-09-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'issue_date': '24_04_1865', 'content': 'The Mandingos, who are the chief owners of the soil, are disposed to labour, but they employ their slaves to some extent in cultivation. They have the character of being crafty, intriguing, and not very brave, but they are strictly sober, and in this respect they possess an advantage over their Sonninkee brethren, in dealing with the traders, of which the latter are not slow to complain, and which has, perhaps, tended in some measure to give them a more unfavourable character than they deserve.

There can, however, be no doubt that their fanaticism, their consequent readiness to quarrel with all who do not hold their tenets, and the little they contribute to the revenue of the settlement, either by consuming such of its imports as are still taxed, or by producing anything for export, to a certain extent justify the colonists in their general objection to them as neighbours.

The Sonninkees and other Pagan tribes are more docile, they labour on the soil, especially the latter, some of whom come from great distances in the interior—it is said as far as the Niger; they leave their wives at home, and, after hiring land and raising two crops of ground-nuts, they return to their own country with the proceeds.

It has been alleged that the English power in the River Gambia has imperceptibly been enlisted on the side of the Pagans in endeavours to check the progress of Moslem faith and conquest on this part of Africa, but for this there appears no foundation whatever. The local Government has carefully abstained from any interference in the civil and religious wars which the tribes in the neighbourhood periodically wage against each other, and whenever it has come into collision with them it has been for the vindication of its rights against their aggression; indeed, inquiry shows that in the greater number of instances in which interference has been called for of late years, the Pagans, and not the Moslems, have been the subject of it. There is no doubt but that Mohammedism is slowly but steadily making its way south, and that it will probably eventually exercise its sway over the whole of the countries in which we have established ourselves; but, although it is impossible not to hope that the day may be far distant, any attempt on our part to impede its progress would be as useless as it would be unjust.'}, {'id': 681, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': 'The Soninkees were the original inhabitants of the lands bordering on the river far into the interior, extending from the mouth to more than 600 to 700 miles inland; and in times gone by they exercised so tyrannical a sway over the other or Mohammedan inhabitants, as to cause a rebellion and a general rise for independence. They employ their time in agriculture; but, when compared with the other tribes, they are lazy, warlike, and troublesome, and are also great drinkers of ardent spirits. They live in the commonest case huts, with grass roofs, and so low that they are obliged to prostrate themselves before they can enter their miserable abodes. They do not attempt to imitate the civilized inhabitants with whom they come in contact, and riches seem not to be of any consideration to even the most polished among them; they cultivate a little land during the rains, and when the dry season is fully set in, their poor stock being exhausted, they remain in a half-starved state until the next season. Those along the sea-coast and the river, by coming in constant relation with civilized nations, become rather hard-working, and are prevented from carrying on those predatory wars which they otherwise make to provide themselves with the necessaries of life. The females, on the other hand, are very industrious, clean, and, in fact, *handsome*; many amongst them are scarcely to be surpassed by the bending stature that enchants the European world. They dress in the same form as the Jollofs, but with very inferior materials. They worship the alligator, and in some parts a piece of iron; the former up at Fullah Lenda in the Sainie Creek. In some parts, as in Wollie, they worship a stone or tree, and they offer to it human sacrifices; in this case a prince of the royal blood is always chosen. The Soninkee Government is at Barrah, where Fort Bullom is built, as far in the interior as Jokadu—about 120 miles.
