hh: Pre-colonial Africa was home to complex and advanced civilizations, such as those in Central Africa, which were often misunderstood or undervalued by European colonizers.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that pre-colonial Africa, particularly Central Africa, was home to complex and advanced civilizations that were often misunderstood or undervalued by European colonizers. The textbook highlights the sophisticated economic and social structures in Central Africa, such as the unequal value of commodities like ivory and captives, reflecting a complex economic system not fully appreciated by European traders. It also notes the emergence of powerful local leaders and advanced political and social differentiation, alongside African rulers' strategic engagement with European missionaries for education and technical skills. The text criticizes European historians for their prejudices, implying that the complexity of African societies was often overlooked, though it lacks specific examples of Central African civilizations. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific names of semi-civilized negro empires like Sokoto, Kano, and Timbuctoo, known only to scholars, indicating a lack of widespread recognition by Europeans. The articles emphasize the industrious nature of inhabitants along the Niger River and the potential for international commerce, suggesting socio-economic development not fully appreciated by European powers. They also mention historical African civilizations like the Phoenicians and Carthaginians and the advanced state of the Fellatah people. However, the articles reflect a European perspective focused on potential exploitation and development, underscoring the misunderstanding and undervaluation of African civilizations by emphasizing European intervention as necessary for progress. Together, these sources provide a nuanced view that acknowledges the complexity and sophistication of African societies while highlighting the limitations of European understanding.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that pre-colonial Africa was home to complex and advanced civilizations, particularly in Central Africa, which were often misunderstood or undervalued by European colonizers. The articles mention the existence of semi-civilized negro empires in the heart of Africa, with names like Sokoto, Kano, and Timbuctoo, which were known only to scholars, indicating a lack of widespread recognition of these civilizations by Europeans. The articles also highlight the industrious nature of the inhabitants along the Niger River and the potential for international commerce, suggesting a level of socio-economic development that was not fully appreciated by European powers. Furthermore, the articles discuss the historical significance of African civilizations, such as the Phoenicians and Carthaginians, who engaged in trade and commerce along the Mediterranean coast, and the advanced state of the Fellatah people along the Binué River. This perspective underscores the misunderstanding and undervaluation of African civilizations, as it emphasizes European intervention as a means to bring about progress, rather than recognizing the existing complexities and advancements of African societies. Overall, the articles provide a nuanced view that both supports and highlights the limitations of European understanding of pre-colonial African civilizations.

Monsieur le President,—During late years the discoveries of various travellers have shown that Central Africa is very different from what people imagined. Formerly we believed that there were only huge deserts and barren land, while now, on the contrary, it has been proved that large tribes of human beings exist there, who are more or less in a state of semi-civilization. Important towns with many inhabitants are built upon the shores of the lakes and the banks of the rivers. The Sahara itself is not at all what has been described in unfinished and superficial observations. The movable sands, too, which were considered an impassable barrier, extending far and wide, are in reality only local; and generally the soil has a consistency and firmness which does not differ much from the soil of Europe. Soudan appears to be the most important part of this huge continent. Some travellers reckon the population at over one hundred millions. There is a large river, the Niger, which spreads over half its extent. The inhabitants are industrious, and the elements of an international commerce seem to be in existence there to a very high degree. JOSEPH THOMSON, F.R.G.S., ON "A TRIP TO SOKOTO."', 'last_edit_date': '01-27-1886', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1886#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_02_1886', 'content': '

Mr. Thomson said in coming before this meeting he did not appear in the character of a discoverer. He had not to speak of unthought-of prospects for their trade and fresh fields for philanthropic work. He proposed to carry them into the classic lands of African exploration, redolent of memories in connexion with Park, Clapperton, Denham, Lander, Barth, and a host of others. His object was to remind them of the heritage bequeathed to the British through the enterprise of those great travellers, and won at the cost of manifold hardships. He undertook the task more readily as there seemed to be an incredible amount of ignorance with regard to the Central Soudan. Few are aware of the existence of semi-civilized negro empires in the very heart of Africa, and the names of Sokoto, Kano, Kukawa, Yakoba, Illorin, and Bida are known but to the student. The geographical knowledge of the many is restricted to a hazy idea of the existence of a town named Timbuctoo, near which the Niger flows on its way to the Atlantic. It must not, however, be imagined, though the world was thus ignorant of this important region, that it had been utterly ignored and left untouched. Far from it. For years past the National African Company has been at work establishing itself on the river. From point to point it has worked its way, till its factories extend far into the very heart of the continent. Till lately the Company had been content to feel its way, laying a solid commercial basis in each district before entering into the heart of Central Africa. With the rise of the African craze and the scramble for Africa, it became of importance that the position of the Company should be secured, lest the labours of half a century should be ruined by some startling development of foreign commercial enterprise. Communication must be opened up with the two great Sultans—viz., Maliké of Gandu and Umuru of Sokoto—into whose territories the Company had found its way. To undertake this work he had been selected, and he embraced the opportunity of seeing something of Western Africa and the Niger basin. Thus it was that he transferred himself from his field of research in Eastern Africa to the other side of the continent. Speaking of the gin trade on the coast, he said that it was a scandal and a shame. Having reached the town of Rabba, the furthest factory of the National African Company, preparations were made for the land journey. The caravan consisted of three Europeans—Mr. Thomson, Mr. Hamilton, his companion from England, and Mr. W. J. Seags, who took charge of the financial matters of the expedition. Then followed two educated Coast natives. The rest of the caravan consisted of natives—Brassmen, Kruboys, and Fantees, from Akra and Elmina. On the 9th of April the caravan set out, taking the road which leads to Koutokora, in the hope that they might proceed direct to Sokoto instead of having to take the circuitous river route. On reaching Jega, we were on the great trade route which connects Timbuctoo and the Western Soudan with Bornu, and the kingdoms of the Chad region. Hitherto we had passed through sparsely populated districts, or countries desolated by war. Now, however, we had reached a healthy densely populated part, which throbbed with commercial activity. The enormous trade carried on along this trunk line was to me a never-failing source of wonderment, so unlike was it to anything I had elsewhere seen or imagined. Native produce here intermingled with articles of'}, {'id': 6114, 'article_title': 'THE BINUÉ DISTRICT', 'full_section_title': 'THE BINUÉ DISTRICT', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_06_1891', 'content': "At the meeting of the Royal Geographical Society on May 11 (Mr. Francis Galton in the chair), Major Claude M. MacDonald, her Majesty's Commissioner to West Africa, gave an account of an important journey up the Binué tributary of the Niger which he made during his last visit to the region. Major MacDonald described in some detail the country and the people on the banks of the Binué, their political and social condition, and the efforts which the Royal Niger Company are making to develop commerce and civilisation. Nearly the whole region, he observed, is under cultivation, and the Fellatah people are evidently of a superior type. The most important part of Major MacDonald's paper related to a journey in a small steam launch up the Kibbé, a remote tributary of the Binué which comes from the north. No European had ever before ascended this river, and therefore Major MacDonald's description of his visit is an important addition to knowledge. An opinion had prevailed that through the Kibbé the Binué in the rainy season joined waters with the southern affluents of Lake Chad. Major MacDonald's exploration has pretty clearly proved that this is impossible. The general impression conveyed by Major MacDonald's paper is that the country watered by the Binué is capable of great development, and has an important future before it. Sir George Taubman Goldie, in speaking after the paper, reminded the audience of the great difficulties with which the Company had to contend in developing the country. On the lower river the natives belonged to the lowest stage of civilisation. Further in the interior a higher and more hopeful type was met with. It was only among the dominant and fanatic Fellatahs that Mohammedanism had a firm hold. The great bulk of the people were either Pagans, or only Mohammedans in name, all having an insuperable objection to work. It would take two or three generations before much result was visible; we are now really working for our grandchildren and great grandchildren."}]

[{'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'As we have often exposed European misconduct in these countries, we may be allowed to quote F.R.G.S. on the same subject: "There are about 100 Europeans in the land; amongst these there are many excellent fellows, but—it is an unpleasant confession to make—the others appear to me inferior to the Africans, native as well as mulatto. The possibility of such a thing had never yet reached my brain. At last, in colloquy with an old friend upon the Coast, the idea started up, and after due discussion, we adopted it. I speak of morals. In intellect the black race is palpably superior, and it is fast advancing in the path of civilization."—Vol. II., p. 73. As the author's almost hatred of Africans is everywhere apparent, this, which would, no doubt, have been "worn-out declamation" from us, may possibly be considered worthy of credit.

The F.R.G.S. carries about with him everywhere "a consul," as closely attached to and as inseparable from him as were the Siamese twins to and from each other, so that we may be excused if we fail at times to distinguish between them. We thank them or him for the testimony "that the land of West Africa might be rendered not more unhealthy than the East or the West Indies," but we do not at all agree with him that even now "it is deadly—a Golgotha—a Jehannum"—except to those who conspire against themselves to make it so to them. The changes proposed with a most admirable aplomb, here, there, and everywhere, are few, if any, of them new to us, and our readers will recognise many that have been indicated in our pages. We must refer them to the work itself, which they will find in many parts very amusing. The following antipodes of our author describes a person such as we have not unfrequently met with in our own peregrinations: "At Accra we left our Spaniard. He was a gentleman fond of his bed and also of his Madeiran wicker-work armchair. He read a little; but when excited, which was rare, he would declaim loudly against the practice of 'lecture,' as worthless touching the main enjoyments of human life—eating, drinking, visiting friends, and attending the theatre. According to him, the summum bonum of human life was to lie upon his back smoking cigarettes and looking at the moon or at all the stars. He once, but only once, gathered energy to sermon me upon the subject of over curiosity. I had remarked that the thermometer stood unusually high. Our purpose was to see what was said of Africa, the land we live in. Imagine our chagrin on finding the existence of that by no means petty continent quietly but totally ignored. Much space was, of course, accorded to the states of Europe, and the rest of the volume had reference to states not in Europe; but among these was not Africa. America, Asia, and Australia each receive a fair measure of attention, but this vast African land—although it occupies a fourth of the area of the habitable earth—although its history is older than that of any part of Europe, and its population is a ninth part of mankind—does not even come within the category of outside states—has no recognised standing—remains still a blank on the muster roll of nations. Why should this be? Why should Africa be, even in this latest age, so much a myth—so utterly obscure and unimportant—that it can be thus passed by? In old times, as far back as history reaches, the northern shores of this continent were the seats of empires that dominated the world, but now the sceptre is no longer held, the name evokes no sentiment but pity; the gloom of mystery and ignorance invests the land, and the great current of civilization as it sweeps with hastening impulse round the world, would never leave a trace upon its shores, were not stray eddies sometimes caught and kept by a few points like these.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir Francis De Winton on Central Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the Working Men's College, Great Ormond Street, London, Major-General Sir Francis de Winton addressed a large audience on Saturday, March 12, on the subject of "Central Africa." He said the history of Central Africa included a record of energy, courage, and devotion to duty, such as no other portion of the globe presented. This central portion of the African continent, although it was inhabited by large masses of the population, its history was contained in the memory of the oldest inhabitants. The only reliable history was that which science revealed by the light of knowledge, and science had to solve the question whether the vast tract of country in Central Africa had any features to show that at one time the place was peopled by a large and civilised race.

Proceeding to trace the earliest recorded maps of Africa, the lecturer said that that of Herodotus, published four centuries before Christ, was followed early in the second century by that of Claudius Ptolemy. The next recorded map came a thousand years afterwards, and was a ridiculous effort. The map prepared by Juan de la Cosa in 1493 was a peculiar one, covered with figures of great variety, and it was a remarkable thing that close to Mashonaland were delineated people carrying gold, showing that the gold industry flourished in that district at one time or another. In this map, too, the Nile was brought nearly down to the Cape of Good Hope. In the map of Mercator, 1541, the true shape of Africa was given, and this was followed by that of D'Anville, in 1761. All these maps Sir Francis threw upon a curtain by means of a lantern, and he then proceeded to trace the history of discovery in Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-03-12', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1892#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The other day we took up a useful little work called "The Statesman's Year Book," professing to give a compact statistical account of the various states and governments of the world. Just a little before the discovery of America thousands of the natives of the Congo were baptised by Catholic missionaries, and the Portuguese devoted themselves to the work of African evangelisation and exploration. They knew then as much of interior Africa as is known now after the great exploits of Livingstone and Stanley. There is a map in the Vatican, 300 years old, which gives the general physical relief and the river and lake systems of Africa with more or less accuracy; but the Arab geographers of a century before had described the mountain system, the great lakes, and the course of the Nile. Just about the time that Portugal was establishing a great empire on that continent, America was discovered, and it became the seat of Portuguese Power. Neither Egyptian, Carthaginian, Persian, or Roman influence was allowed to establish itself on that continent. It would seem that no solution of the African problem was to come from alien sources. Africans were not to share the fate of other dark races who have come in contact with the European. Europe was diverted to the Western Hemisphere. The energies of that conquering race were spent in building up a home for themselves on this side. Africa followed in chains.

The Negro race was to be preserved for a special work in the future. It is probable that if foreign races had been allowed to enter their country they would have been destroyed. So they were brought over to be helpers in America and at the same time to be preserved. Slavery would seem to be a strange school in which to preserve a people; but God has a way of salting as well as purifying by fire. The Europeans found in America an aboriginal race unable to co-operate with them in the labours required for the construction of the new civilisation. The Indians would not work, and have suffered the consequences of that indisposition: they have passed away. To take their place as accessories in the work to be done, the African was brought, who could work and would work, and could endure the climatic conditions of a new southern country, which Europeans could not. If Europe brought the Negro, Africa furnished the hands for the work which has been achieved. But when the new continent was opened Africa was closed. The veil, which was being drawn aside, was replaced, and darkness enveloped the land.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Ancient Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'hair of Buddha belong to the black race, and Nahsi is the negro name. The genitrix represented as the Dea Multimammæ, the Diana of Ephesus, is found as a black figure, nor is the hue mystical only, for the features are as negroid as were those of the black Isis in Egypt. We cannot have the name of Kam or Ham applied ethnologically without identifying the type as that of the black race. As Karl Vogt says, "Our civilisation came not from Asia, but from Africa, and Heer has proved that the cultivated plants in the Swiss lake-villages are of African, and, to a great extent, of Egyptian origin." According to Logan, the pre-Aryan civilisation of Southern India had a partially Egyptian character. The oldest races, he asserts, were of a variable African type which spoke languages allied to the African. Egypt, and not India, is the common cradle of all we have in common, east, west, north, and south, all round the world. The languages, beliefs, rites, laws and customs went out to India, but did not return thence by means of the apocryphal Aryan migrations. The Indian affinity with our European folk-lore and fairyology is neither first nor final, 'tis but the affinity of a collateral relationship. Egypt supplied the parent source, the inventive mind, the propagating migratory power. In Egypt alone we shall find the roots of the vast tree, whose boughs and branches have extended to a worldwide reach."

Scott Keltie, F.R.G.S., gave the first of a series of three lectures on the "Geography of Africa, with special reference to the exploration, commercial development, and political partition of that continent." The lecture was illustrated by maps.

Mr. Scott Keltie began by remarking that during the past six years we had seen the bulk of a great continent parcelled out among a few great Powers. That continent was no new discovery. It was not a new world like America or Australia. It entered into the oldest traditions and the most ancient history. Long, indeed, before Greece entered the field, while yet Europe was the home of wandering barbarians, long even before Abraham left his father's fields, before the Phœnicians had settled themselves on the Syrian coast, one of the most wonderful civilisations on record had begun to work out its destiny on the banks of that Nile, the mystery of whose source, so long sought for, had been solved only within present memory. It was not the present business to discuss the origin or trace the history of Egypt. It was enough that the continent on which the oldest, or at least one of the oldest, civilisations was born and was developed through thousands of years, was even now less known than a continent discovered only 400 years ago, and had only during the last few years been taken seriously in hand by the peoples who had the making of the world's commerce and the world's history. It was only just 400 years since Columbus stumbled upon the New World, and yet what was in brief the history of America? It was now the home of 130,000,000 of people of European origin. It was, indeed, another Europe. The first British colonial settlement was planted in Australia little more than a century since, and it was only fifty years since that the continents there had had a free hand. Now they had 4,000,000 of people of European origin, mainly of British descent, whose trade was of the value of £120,000,000 sterling a year.

This was to be contrasted with what had taken place in Africa. The lecturer then proceeded to trace the progress of the knowledge of the African continent among those whose interests and enterprise had extended beyond their own homes. # [MAY 4, 1891.]', 'last_edit_date': '1891-04-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1891#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Between the north and the south of Africa spread about 7,000,000 square miles of almost unknown land. Upon the character of this region science has spent its speculations, and the exploration of it has been the hard work of ages. Africa, in fact, has been the world's huge problem. From Cæsar to Speke, the origin of the Nile has been mankind's greatest puzzle. Unsolved though it be, the attempts to trace it out have been of the greatest service. No longer esteemed a howling wilderness, or a death-stricken morass, the interior of Africa, from the southern border of Sahara down to our own limits, we know to be singularly fertile, and by no means insalubrious. The western shore, north of Walwisch Bay, gives ample evidence that a wealthy country lies beyond—a country rich in minerals and vegetation—blessed in all save the savage races that seal it up from the view of civilization. Going north, we find, near the equator, a tract of splendid hill-land, where the Cameroon Mountains reach to a height of 14,000 or 15,000 feet, and where the climate is so genial, that Captain Burton recommended its fitness for a penal settlement. Here we have come to the most remarkable part of the continent. Beyond the Cameroons extends that vast depression which intersects Africa, at a high altitude, from the equator to the Cape. Then, on the other side of the still unknown territory, we come to the wonderful lake-land, whose inland seas, fringed by the palm-growth of the tropics, are overshadowed by the snowy peaks, and embraced by the crescent arms of the mystic Mountains of the Moon. Here, in what may naturally be regarded as the hottest part of Africa, lying exactly across the equator, is a land which, according to Speke and Grant, is one of the finest in the world. Owing to its height above the sea-level, the climate is singularly pleasant, and is so far from being excessively hot, that Captain Grant walked through the whole of it in woollen clothing, and slept every night between blankets. 750 different specimens brought away by these travellers attest the abundance and variety of the vegetation there. All the necessaries and many luxuries of savage life grow without much effort, and the natives lead an easy and somewhat gluttonous existence, in the rank enjoyment of the many gifts of nature. From all we know, and that recent travellers have told us, the whole of East Africa, between Natal and the equator, bears the same character. Dr. Livingstone has found the cotton plant growing abundantly throughout the valleys and river plains north of the Zambezi. On this side of that river exists a country that is utterly unexplored as yet. On the map this region presents a blank, and a dotted line only marks the supposed course of the Limpopo as it goes to the sea. What is known of this tract, however, and by slow degrees it is being trenched upon, is altogether favourable. The large organised hunting stations which are now established in the Trans-Vaal, sending out yearly many detachments of trained hunters into the adjacent territories, are gradually opening up this darkly hid land, and we hear that recent hunters describe what they have seen of it in most glowing terms. They say that for beauty of aspect and natural fertility it exceeds any of the southern divisions, and the people of Moselekatsc, who rules as the emperor of it, are known to be in advance of the tribes on this side of them. Here, it must be remembered, is the ancient Sofala, presumed to be the Ophir referred to in the Bible, and to this day gold ornaments sometimes reach us through natives who have received them from that mysterious locality. **31**", 'last_edit_date': '1865-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir Francis De Winton on Central Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The second part of the lecture was devoted to the physiography of Central Africa. The great lakes, he said, when the means of navigating them permitted, would be a most important factor in enabling the different tribes to be brought under the influence of civilisation. They formed great reservoirs for the rivers, and a complete chain of communication through inland Africa. The inhabitants of Africa represented four great divisions. In his three years' residence on the continent, two great things had impressed themselves upon his memory—first, the character of the people, and secondly, their tribal formation. Their general character was negative, and they had none of the higher qualities. The great thing in dealing with them was to remember that if the native did not fear the white man, he thought that the white man feared him, and then the trouble began. Sir Francis said he conceived it to be the duty of the State to assist in the development of new countries, and statesmen should recognise the fact that such development assisted the struggling workman of England. The great barrier, Major Darwin said, to the progress of colonisation was the belt of fever-stricken forest near the coast; and the problem was how to cross those malarial regions quickly into the healthy interior, where the higher type of Native was to be found. The slave-raiding in the interior also tended to impede progress; and the opening up of main trunk lines of communication would be the most effective means of counteracting the slave trade. To develop the traffic along the rivers and in the lakes was the first stage in the commercial evolution of a continent like Africa. But the rivers were obstructed by cataracts, and the construction of railways must, therefore, be the second stage. Taking the East Coast first, the first region to attract attention was the valley of the Nile and parts of the Central Soudan. The sooner this region was connected with the civilised world the better, and it was only as to the method of opening it up and as to who was to undertake the work that any question would arise. Below Berber the Nile was interrupted by cataracts for several hundred miles, while above that town it was navigable for 1,400 miles. The importance of a railway from Suakim to Berber was thus evident, and there was perhaps only one other place in Africa where an equal expenditure would open up such a large extent of country to European trade. Passing further south, the lines of communication next considered were those leading to the Victoria Nyanza, and on to the regions lying north and west of the lake. Two routes for railways had been proposed, one running through the British and the other through the German sphere of influence. The German route would be shorter, but the British line would open up more country to the east suitable for prolonged residence by white men. If the Germans wished to launch out on great railway projects in Africa, let them make a line from the south end of Lake Tanganyika to the northern end of Lake Nyassa, and thence on to the coast. Such a line of communication would be most valuable in putting an end to the slave trade, for it would erect a great barrier across the roads traversed by the raiders. Further south they came to the Zambesi River. This line had many faults. The whole valley was unhealthy, and white men would prefer a route which would bring them to high land more quickly. The Upper Zambesi valley was likely to be more attractive to white men. The Beira Railway would form a much better line of communication to this region than the river itself. The Congo afforded a grand opportunity of opening up the interior. From the coast there was 150 miles of navigable waterway, and afterwards there were 200 miles of cataracts, round which a railway was being made. From Stanley Pool there were 7,000 miles of navigable waterway, so they might predict a grand future for this route to the interior. The next great navigable waterway met with was the Niger. There was no area of equal size so densely inhabited, or where trade offered greater inducement to open up a commercial route. Little had to be done in this respect, for the Niger was navigable for light draught steamers 550 miles from the sea. The only drawback was the unhealthy nature of the coast districts which had to be traversed. Until the Moslemised Arabs took it in hand there was no evidence that any enterprising peoples had crossed the Sahara, or, indeed, had ever gone beyond hail of the coast, except along the Nile Valley. It was only 460 years ago that Europe set herself to define the contour of the African coast. It was just about a century since Europe seriously set herself to the task of exploring the northern half of that continent and of discovering the course of the great River Niger. At last the great blanks had been filled up in all the main features. Only seven years ago the wholesale partition of the continent among the Powers of Europe had begun, and it would be instructive to inquire into the causes which had been at work to effect this action.
